assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 8% (Critically Depleted) for the Pale-headed Brush-finch is due to the species being Absent in three of four spatial units, and only Present in the fourth. The Pale-headed Brush-finch has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, the Pale-headed Brush-finch would almost certainly be extinct. The species has a Conservation Dependence of Zero; even if conservation actions were to stop, the species would likely remain Present in its only extant spatial unit over the next 10 years. The Pale-headed Brush-finch has a Low Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, if conservation continues, it is expected that its score would double (to 16%) as the species expands in its current spatial unit. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Pale-headed Brush-finch to be reintroduced in the spatial units where it is currently Absent, and to become Functional where it currently exists, leading to a score of 75%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for the Pale-headed Brush-finch is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 20% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Burrowing Bettong being Absent in 36/46 spatial units. The Burrowing Bettong has a High Conservation Legacy; without reintroductions in areas where invasive predators are excluded, the species would have a score of only 7%. There is a High Conservation Dependence; if predator exclosures were removed, those spatial units would be extirpated over a 10-year period, bringing the score to 10%. The Burrowing Bettong has a Low Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, reintroduction is proposed in one spatial unit (Dirk Hartog Island), leading to a score of 21%. Finally, the Recovery Potential within 100 years is Indeterminate, as climate change could reduce the viability of reintroduction projects throughout much of the range, and it is unclear whether introduced predator populations can be effectively controlled.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Australasian Marsupial and Monotreme Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: John Woinarski (email: John.Woinarski@cdu.edu.au) and Diana Fisher (email: d.fisher@uq.edu.au)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Chris Johnson (email: c.n.johnson@utas.edu.au)

assessments.justification:
Ridgway's Hawk has a Species Recovery Score of 17% (Critically Depleted) due to its extirpation from four of the eight spatial units within its indigenous range (Central and North Haiti, Cordillera Septentrional, Gonâve Island, and Sierra de Neiba/Sierra de Baoruco). In the remaining four units (Cordillera Central, Los Haitises, Punta Cana, and Tiburon Peninsula), the species is Present but not Viable. In both Punta Cana and Cordillera Central, Ridgway's Hawk had been lost until translocation efforts in the 2010s successfully reintroduced individuals. In Los Haitises, surveys in the 2000s revealed that extremely low reproductive success made the subpopulation unsustainable without intensive management. Conservation interventions—including treating nests and nestlings for Philornis larval parasites and engaging local communities to reduce persecution—have steadily increased the species' numbers in this area. Without these and other conservation efforts, the hawk would likely have been extirpated from seven of the eight spatial units by now, reflecting a High Conservation Legacy. If conservation efforts were to cease, the species would likely be rapidly extirpated in Punta Cana and Cordillera Central, as the translocated populations are not yet self-sustaining. However, past conservation actions would likely allow short-term persistence in Los Haitises and Tiburon Peninsula, indicating a Low Conservation Dependence. With continued management, the population in Los Haitises could grow to a Viable level, and populations in other spatial units could at least be maintained (a Low Conservation Gain). In the long term, sustained management, education, and reintroduction efforts could restore the species to at least a Present status in seven of the eight spatial units, with most of these populations reaching Viable or Functional levels—demonstrating a High Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Johnson, J.A., McClure, C.J.W., Buechley, E.R., Thorstrom, R., Curti, M., Suarez, C. & Diaz, G.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Tarzan Chameleon (Calumma tarzan) has a Species Recovery Score of 17% (Critically Depleted) due to its extirpation from two of the four spatial units within its indigenous range and its presence in a non-Viable state in the remaining two. The species is highly sensitive to disturbance, and the majority of the remaining population is confined to protected areas and a 'classified' area (which permits limited resource extraction but prohibits habitat clearance). Without these protections, the species would likely persist in only one of its spatial units—its current stronghold—and in a severely depleted state (a Low but significant Conservation Legacy). Deforestation rates are accelerating across Madagascar, and despite existing protections, the species continues to face illegal habitat destruction. If these protections were removed, habitat loss would intensify rapidly, likely leading to the loss of its stronghold and complete extinction (a High Conservation Dependence). However, conservation measures are expected to continue, with plans to upgrade the classified area to a fully protected area. Additionally, a local conservation organisation is actively implementing various interventions in one of the spatial units, including community education and engagement, alternative livelihoods (such as training locals as beekeepers and forest rangers), ranger patrols for enforcement, and habitat connectivity restoration through corridor planting. With increasing numbers of locals transitioning from slash-and-burn agriculture to beekeeping, population declines in this unit appear to be slowing and could stabilise within the next decade, making the unit Viable. However, there are currently no plans for reintroductions to areas where the species has been extirpated (resulting in a Low Conservation Gain). In the long term, conservationists should aim to restore habitat connectivity through reforestation, expand alternative livelihood programmes, and improve habitat management. With these efforts, along with reintroductions to extirpated areas, the species could become Present or Viable in all spatial units, leading to a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Acigöl Killifish being Critically Endangered in its one extant spatial unit; this is due to competition with invasive Eastern Mosquitofish, habitat degradation, and climate change. This killifish has a Conservation Legacy of Zero because, other than restrictions related to the use of the lake water, no major actions have taken place in the past to protect the species. However, the species has a Medium Conservation Gain, since there are plans to create a safety net population via assisted colonisation, and ongoing research and actions to manage the invasive mosquitofish. The species has a High Conservation Dependence, given that without conservation actions to manage the invasive mosquitofish, current populations will likely decrease to extinction and the safety net population would likely not establish. Finally, the Acigöl Killifish has an Indeterminate Recovery Potential; while the removal of the invasive Eastern Mosquitofish and the establishment of the safety net population are likely within the next 100 years, recovery is limited by climate change and associated habitat loss if lakes dry.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Cliffe, A., Yoğurtçuoğlu, B., Pearce-Kelly, P. & Johnson, L.
assessments.facilitators: Young, R.E., Cygan, M.G.W. & McMurdough Hamilton, T.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 79% (Moderately Depleted) is due to Alpine Ibex having been restored to functionality in five out of eight spatial units. The Alpine Ibex has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, the Alpine Ibex would almost certainly be extinct today as the result of intense hunting pressure between the 16th and 19th centuries. There is a Low Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species would not show much change over a 10-year period, falling only to 75%. The Alpine Ibex has a Conservation Gain of Zero; while there are plans to bolster the genetic diversity of the species, it is not expected that effects large enough to change the state in a spatial unit would be seen within a 10-year period. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Alpine Ibex to become at least Viable in all spatial units, and Functional in most, leading to a score of 87%. This makes the Recovery Potential for Alpine Ibex Low, relative to the current score.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Brambilla, A., Bassano, B., Biebach, I., Cavailhes, J., Gressman, G., Grossen, C., Keller, L.F., Toïgo, C. & Von Hardenberg, A.
assessments.reviewer_names: Milner-Gulland, E., Grace, M.K. & Mallon, D.P.

assessments.justification:
The Addax has a Species Recovery Score of 14% (Critically Depleted) because it is Absent from four of the seven spatial units within its indigenous range, and Present but not Viable in the remaining three. Conservation impact on this species so far has been limited. While there are captive breeding and reintroduction programmes underway, these have not yet resulted in new subpopulations that meet the criteria for being considered wild, meaning Conservation Legacy is currently Zero. However, within the next 10 years, two reintroduced subpopulations are expected to meet these criteria, leading to the species becoming Present in a spatial unit where it is currently considered Absent—resulting in a Low, but significant, Conservation Gain. If these efforts were to stop now, the species would likely retain its current depleted state for the next decade, indicating a Conservation Dependence score of Zero. In the next 100 years, reintroducing the species to all the spatial units within its indigenous range could be feasible. With additional measures, such as habitat protection and hunting prevention, Viable populations could potentially be established in four spatial units. Therefore, the Recovery Potential is assessed as High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Species Recovery Score of 35% (Largely Depleted) is due to the Dibatag being threatened in the only spatial unit in which it has been known to occur. Conservation Legacy and Gain are both Zero for this species, as little to no conservation action has taken place within its indigenous range, and no additional measures are planned. However, the species may benefit from legal protection and border controls; if legal protection were revoked, it is likely that the status would deteriorate slightly in the next 10 years, reflecting a Low Conservation Dependence. Recovery Potential is Medium, because it would be possible to reverse declines and restore a non-threatened population. This would require the implementation of protected areas, increased research and monitoring efforts, and the establishment of ex situ subpopulations.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Species Recovery Score of 75% (Moderately Depleted) is due to Blue Cranes being Functional in two spatial units, Viable in the third, and Present in the fourth. The Blue Crane has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action including protected areas, campaigns to reduce human-wildlife conflict, and steps taken to reduce mortality from collisions with powerlines, Blue Cranes would have a score of 33% today. There is a Medium Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that its status would deteriorate across its range over a 10-year period, bringing the score to 42%. Blue Cranes have a Medium Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, if conservation continues, it is expected that the species will become Functional in three out of four spatial units, leading to a score of 92%. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Blue Crane to become Functional across its range, leading to a score of 100%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for Blue Cranes is Medium, relative to its already high Species Recovery Score.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Craig, C.A., Scott, A. & Scott, M.

assessments.justification:
Pantura has a Species Recovery Score of 63% (Moderately Depleted) due to its varying status across the 10 plateaus within its indigenous range, ranging from fully ecologically Functional to being at risk of local extirpation. Most of these plateaus fall within conservation zones, national parks, or wildlife sanctuaries. Without this protection, pressures from excessive tourism, mining, wind farm construction, and other human activities would have likely led to the species' extirpation from multiple plateaus and near-extirpation from others (High Conservation Legacy). Similarly, if conservation efforts were to cease now, these threats would intensify, causing many subpopulations to be lost or pushed to the brink of extirpation within a decade (High Conservation Dependence). While action plans exist for some plateaus and are expected to benefit the species, the extent of their impact over the next 10 years remains uncertain (Indeterminate Conservation Gain). If planned conservation measures are effectively implemented, if currently unprotected sites receive protection, and if anthropogenic pressures are reduced where they pose a significant threat, it may be possible for all plateaus to support Functional subpopulations of the species within 100 years. However, the long-term uncertainty of such projections, coupled with potential climate change impacts, makes the species' future recovery difficult to predict (Indeterminate Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Abeli, T., Narasimhan, D. & Cygan, M.G.W.

assessments.justification:
The American Bison has a Species Recovery Score of 17% (Critically Depleted), as it is Absent from many of its indigenous spatial units. Nonetheless, the majority of extant herds within the species' indigenous range today are the result of reintroductions, so the species has a High Conservation Legacy. If hunting pressure increased, the species' Recovery Score would decline over the next 10 years to 11%, but the the species would not be driven to extinction over that time period (relatively Low Conservation Dependence). Additional reintroductions and stabilisation of existing herds could increase the score to 21% over the next 10 years (Low Conservation Gain). Over 100 years, the species could be Functional in most areas where it is currently extant, though reintroductions in other areas are complicated by human pressures (Medium Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Rogers, L.R., Ranglack, D.H. & Plumb, G.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 59% (Moderately Depleted) is due to the White Shark being threatened (Present) in four spatial units, Viable in three, and Functional in just two. The four conservation impact metrics, however, are Indeterminate; more research is required to evaluate the past and potential future impacts of conservation for this species.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Rigby, C.L., Huveneers, C. & Grace, M.K.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Keel-scaled Boa being Absent from 11 of the 13 spatial units comprising the species' indigenous range. Its absence is due to the arrival of non-native mammalian predators, resulting in local extinctions. The Keel-scaled Boa has a High Conservation Legacy since without past conservation actions involving invasive species eradication, habitat restoration and successful translocations, the species would have been lost from all the spatial units, and the species would have gone extinct. There is a High Conservation Dependence, because without strict biosecurity interventions and island monitoring preventing invasive species establishment, it is unlikely the islands would remain predator-free, and past experience shows how rapidly native reptiles are lost from islands in Mauritius following predator invasion. The Conservation Gain is Zero as planned conservation actions over the next 10 years are not expected to change the species' status on islands where the species has already been lost (due to habitat degradation and invasive species), but the effect of future conservation is expected to maintain the currently Functional populations. The Recovery Potential is Low, as the re-establishment of a population of Keel-scaled Boas is only expected in one additional spatial unit, given the widespread nature of several invasive species across mainland Mauritius.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Cole, N., Tatayah, V., Seeneevassin, P., Young, R.E. & Ruhomaun, K.

common_names.name: Boa de L'Ile Ronde de Dussumier

assessments.justification:
The North American Beaver has a Species Recovery Score of 83% (Slightly Depleted), because it is fully Functional in three of the six spatial units within its indigenous range, and Viable (but not Functional) in the remaining three. Trapping regulations have played a crucial role in the species' recovery, allowing it to rebound in many areas after historical declines driven by the fur trade. Moreover, conservation translocations have helped bolster depleted subpopulations and reintroduce beavers to areas where they had been extirpated. Without these interventions, it is estimated that the Recovery Score would be as low as 44%, reflecting a High Conservation Legacy. If trapping regulations were removed today, beavers would likely decline in some parts of their range; however, past conservation efforts have brought the species to a level where these declines would not affect its short-term recovery status in the majority of spatial units. As a result, the species is assessed as having Low Conservation Dependence. With ongoing trapping regulations, along with habitat protection and restoration, the species is expected to maintain its current status in the short term (Zero Conservation Gain). Over the next century, additional efforts such as habitat restoration, targeted recovery assessments for at-risk subpopulations, and relocation programmes could help the species recover further toward its historical baseline. However, since its current Recovery Score is already relatively high, its Recovery Potential is assessed as Low.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 67% (Moderately Depleted) is due to the Black Stork being Functional in one of its two spatial units, and Present in the other. The Black Stork has a Medium Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, including protected areas, the Black Stork would have a score of 50%, as it is not likely the species would be Functional in any spatial unit. Its Conservation Dependence category is Zero; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species status would not change quickly enough to trigger a change in state over the next 10 years. The Black Stork has a Medium Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, if conservation continues, it is expected that the currently Present spatial unit could become Viable, leading to a score of 84%. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for The Black Stork to be Functional in all spatial units, leading to a score of 100%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for The Black Stork is Medium (relative to its current score).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 13% (Critically Depleted) is due to Philippine Crocodiles being Absent in 11/18 spatial units and only Present in the rest. Philippine Crocodiles have a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, Philippine Crocodiles would only persist in three spatial units today. There is a High Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species would go extinct in all but one spatial unit over a 10-year period. Philippine Crocodiles have a High Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, planned reintroductions and continued conservation could begin to achieve Viable spatial units, leading to a score of 28% (more than double the current score). Finally, within 100 years it is unclear what could happen; the impacts of future habitat loss, dam building and climate change are uncertain. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for Philippine Crocodiles is Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Manolis, C., Hoffmann, M. & Grace, M.K.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 57% (Moderately Depleted) is due to the Roatán Spiny-tailed Iguana being Absent in one spatial unit, Functional in three, and threatened (Present) in the remaining three. The Roatán Spiny-tailed Iguana has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, the Roatán Spiny-tailed Iguana would almost certainly be threatened throughout its entire range today. Conservation Dependence is Indeterminate; though the best estimate is that without continued conservation, the species could become extirpated in many spatial units over 10 years, there is uncertainty in this prediction. The Roatán Spiny-tailed Iguana has a Conservation Gain of Zero; within a 10-year period, the best estimate is that the Recovery Score will not change. Finally, the best estimate is that over 100 years, the species could become Functional in most spatial units with sustained conservation effort, but there is uncertainty in this prediction. Therefore, the Recovery Potential is Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 24% (Largely Depleted) is due to the species being Absent in one spatial unit (reflecting the extinction of the subspecies Diceros bicornis longipes), and Present in a threatened state in two others, with only the South-western unit currently not threatened (Viable). The species has a High Conservation Legacy because of successful conservation actions that halted population declines; without these actions, extinction was a possibility for all spatial units, but especially the Eastern spatial unit. The Black Rhino's Conservation Dependence reflects that, while population declines would be expected within the next 10 years if conservation actions stopped, it is unlikely that any spatial units would become extinct within that time. However, it should be noted that while this Conservation Dependence of 10% is classified as Low, it is very close to the threshold for Medium Conservation Dependence (>10%). The Black Rhino has a Medium Conservation Gain, reflecting that if population recovery continues on course for the next 10 years, the species will be at least Viable in three of four spatial units. The Recovery Potential for the species is High, as it would be possible to restore Functional populations over much of the Eastern, South-central, and Southwestern spatial units, and to restore some Black Rhinos to the Western spatial unit.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Ferreira, S.M., Knight, M.H., Vigne, L. & Goldenberg, S.

assessments.justification:
The Sea Otter has a Species Recovery Score of 47% (Largely Depleted). This reflects its varying state across the 20 spatial units within its indigenous range: it is Absent in four, Present in nine, Viable in two, and Functional in five. The species was hunted to near extinction during the maritime fur trade (1741–1911) but made a significant recovery following international protection in 1911 and subsequent reintroductions. Without these interventions, the species would likely be extinct today, highlighting a High Conservation Legacy. Despite rebounding from historical lows, the Sea Otter remains threatened in many areas, with ongoing declines in some parts of its range. If protections were removed, the species would likely be extirpated from most spatial units due to hunting, persecution, and harassment, demonstrating a High Conservation Dependence. With current conservation measures in place, the species is expected to maintain its current status in most spatial units, with potential recolonisation of some Absent units over the next decade through natural immigration. Consequently, Conservation Gain is assessed as Low but significant. Further recovery to Functional levels across all spatial units within 100 years is feasible with targeted conservation actions such as translocations, harassment prevention, and protection from harvest. In regions where predation by Orcas poses a significant threat, continued protections for Grey Whales – the primary prey of Orcas – are expected to help reduce predation pressure on Sea Otters in the long term. The potential for full restoration qualifies the species for a High Recovery Potential rating.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Loy, A., Duplaix, N. & Cygan, M.G.W.

assessments.justification:
The Mauritius Kestrel has a Species Recovery Score of 17% (Critically Depleted), primarily as a result of massive forest loss on Mauritius. However, without the reintroductions that have taken place, as well as provision of nest boxes and supplemental feeding, the species would almost certainly be extinct today (High Conservation Legacy). If these actions were to cease, then the species would decline over the next 10 years to a score of 10% (Low Conservation Dependence). Over that same time frame, the species is expected to remain stable with continued conservation (Zero Conservation Gain). In the long term, it will be possible to establish subpopulations in all remaining habitat, and even achieve some Functional subpopulations; however, the large-scale forest conversion limits the maximum predicted score that could be achieved over 100 years to 30% (Medium Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 8% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Burmese Star Tortoise being Absent in half of its spatial units and Critically Endangered in the remaining two, reflecting the species' history of decline due to poaching for human consumption. The species has a High Conservation Legacy, since without past conservation actions involving successful translocations, the species would have been lost from all spatial units. The Conservation Dependence is also High, because without antipoaching measures it is likely that the species would disappear from the wild, and the Conservation Gain is High, because within a 10-year timeframe it is expected that reintroduced populations will reach a Viable state in two spatial units. The Burmese Star Tortoise has a High Recovery Potential within 100 years because the goal for the species is to be reintroduced in all suitable protected areas in Myanmar, but recovery is limited since reintroductions are restricted only to protected areas due to poaching; therefore some of the range is expected to remain unoccupied by the species.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

Newsletters: Chelonian Conservation and Biology (http://www.chelonian.org/ccb/); Turtle and Tortoise Newsletter (http://www.chelonian.org/crf-publications/turtle-and-tortoise-newsletter/); TurtleLog Online Newsletter (http://www.iucn-tftsg.org/turtlelog_online_newsletter/)

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 33% (Moderately Depleted) is due to the Bolson Tortoise being threatened in the only spatial unit in which it currently occurs. The species enjoys legal protection and protection within a biosphere reserve; however, the level of habitat degradation within the biosphere is not much lower than outside it, and the impact of legal protection is difficult to determine. Thus, the Conservation Legacy is Zero, but there is some uncertainty in this, and it is nonetheless expected that without past conservation, this species would persist, but in much lower numbers than seen today. However, Conservation Dependence is High; because of the recent increase in high-intensity grazing and agriculture occurring in the area, the land protected by the biosphere is increasingly in demand for deep drilling for groundwater and intense agriculture, which (together with other threats) would likely drive the species to extinction within 10 years if protection was removed. Bolson Tortoises have been reintroduced into a large area of private land in New Mexico, but these will not reproduce in the next 10 years and so cannot be considered when assessing the short-term Conservation Gain (which is predicted to be Zero). However, within the next 100 years, this population will likely be considered wild and will hopefully have reached a Viable size. There are plans to reintroduce the species to two additional sites, and it is hoped that these populations will also be Viable within 100 years. While there is uncertainty around the effect of climate change on the success of these reintroductions, the Recovery Potential is categorised as High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: van Dijk, P.P. & Castañeda Gaytán, G.

assessments.justification:
The Balsas Shiner has a Species Recovery Score of 58% (Moderately Depleted) as it is Viable but not Functional in three of the four spatial units within its indigenous range, while in the remaining unit, it is Present but not Viable. In the main spring of the El Texcal spatial unit, past threats included two invasive fish species, the Rainbow Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) and the Variable Platyfish (Xiphophorus variatus), as well as the invasive plant Egeria densa. Since 2000, local communities have actively controlled Egeria, and both the trout and platys have been eradicated. Without these efforts, the species would not have remained Viable in this unit. In the Cuernavaca spatial unit, legal protections for streams have prevented urban expansion that would have otherwise polluted the waterways and led to local extirpation. In contrast, the other two spatial units have seen minimal conservation impact to date. As a result, Conservation Legacy is assessed as Medium. If conservation measures were abandoned, threats such as pollution, invasive species, and unsustainable management would likely degrade all streams, but the extent to which this would impact the species remains uncertain. Therefore, Conservation Dependence is classified as Indeterminate. Future conservation efforts over the next decade show promise, with community-based action plans, land management initiatives, and invasive species eradication programmes in the pipeline. These measures are expected to restore the species to Functional levels in most spatial units, supporting an assessment of Medium Conservation Gain. Over the long term, sustainable spring management and continued invasive species removal could maintain three of the four spatial units at a Functional level, leading to a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) is due to the Cheer Pheasant being Present (that is, non-Viable and non-Functional) in all spatial units. The Cheer Pheasant has a Medium Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, the Cheer Pheasant would have a score of 22%, as it is likely it would have gone extinct in one of its three spatial units. The species' Conservation Dependence and Conservation Gain are both Zero, as it is (respectively) unlikely that the species would go extinct in any spatial unit in the span of 10 years, even if all conservation stopped, and the species is likely to remain threatened in all spatial units over that time period even with continued conservation. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Cheer Pheasant to become Functional in all spatial units, leading to a score of 100%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for the Cheer Pheasant is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
Roti Snake-necked Turtle is Critically Depleted (Species Recovery Score 8%) as it has a very restricted range, occurring in only two spatial units. It is Possibly Extinct in the Wild in one spatial unit (assessed as most likely Absent), as a result of threats including predation by non-native fish and high poaching pressure, and Critically Endangered in the other spatial unit. This species has a Conservation Legacy of Zero because even with legal protection of the species and its occurrence within a protected area in Timor-Leste, it is still believed to be declining. The Conservation Gain is Zero  despite the establishment of a reintroduction programme on Roti Island. This is due to the time-lag in introduced individuals being considered wild, meaning the status is not expected to change in either of the spatial units within 10 years. Future re-assessments of this species will better reflect the impact of this species reintroduction work. The Conservation Dependence is also Zero because there are currently no targeted conservation or threat mitigation actions in the remaining population on Timor-Leste, and none are planned to be implemented in the short-term future. It is likely that even with the current national park and legal protection, the species will still be lost. The Recovery Potential for this species is High because there is a breeding and reintroduction programme and with control of predatory fish and habitat restoration, this species could be restored in multiple lakes within its indigenous range.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
Coryphaeschna perrensi has a Species Recovery Score of 56% (Moderately Depleted) because it is Present but not Viable in two of its six spatial units, and Viable but not Functional in the remaining four. Protected areas have helped maintain habitat integrity; however, since the species persists outside protected areas in much of its range, it would only be slightly more depleted without this protection. As a result, both Conservation Legacy and Conservation Dependence are assessed as Low. With ongoing protections, the species is expected to maintain its current status over the next decade, indicating Zero Conservation Gain. In the long term, with significant conservation efforts, the species could become Viable in all but one spatial unit. However, full recovery remains limited below Functional levels due to projected habitat loss and degradation from climate change, leading to a Low Recovery Potential assessment.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 11% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Jamaican Rock Iguana being found in only two of six spatial units today, and threatened in both. The Jamaican Rock Iguana has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, the Jamaican Rock Iguana would almost certainly be extinct today. There is a High Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that one of the two remaining spatial units would be extirpated over a 10-year period, bringing the score to 5%. The Jamaican Rock Iguana has a High Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, given planned reintroductions and invasive species control, it is expected that the species would become Viable in two spatial units and remain Present in a third, leading to a score of 28%. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Jamaican Rock Iguana to become Viable or Functional over a substantial proportion of its indigenous range, leading to a score of 61%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for the Jamaican Rock Iguana is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 16% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Telfair's Skink being Absent from 11 of the 14 Spatial Units delineated considering the species indigenous range: the loss was due to the arrival of invasive predator species that led to island extinctions. The Telfair's Skink has a High Conservation Legacy since without past conservation actions involving invasive species eradication and successful translocations, the species would have been lost from all the Spatial Units, in short, the species would be extinct. There is a High Conservation Dependence, because without invasive species control and prevention it is unlikely the islands would remain predator free, but the Conservation Gain is Zero given that future actions in a 10 year time frame can not change the species status in islands where the species has already been lost (due to habitat degradation and invasive species) and the effect of future conservation is expected to be the maintenance of currently Functional subpopulations. Finally, the Recovery Potential within 100 years is Medium, given there is a potential for habitat restoration in Gabriel Island that could sustain a translocated Telfair's Skink population in a Spatial Unit where its currently extinct.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 17% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Northern Sportive Lemur being Absent in one of its two spatial units, and highly threatened (Present) in the other due to habitat loss for charcoal production and hunting. The Northern Sportive Lemur has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, especially the establishment of the Montagne des Français protected area, the Northern Sportive Lemur would almost certainly be extinct today. There is a High Conservation Dependence; if protections were to stop, it is expected that the species would be driven to extinction within 10 years. The Northern Sportive Lemur has a Medium Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, if the planned actions of forest restoration, reforestation and monitoring are carried out as planned, it is expected that the species may go from Present to Viable in its extant spatial unit, leading to a score of 34%. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Northern Sportive Lemur to be reintroduced to its second spatial unit, and even become Functional in both as a result of reforestation and habitat restoration, as well as enforcement of protected area laws and a reduction in charcoal production, leading to a score of 100%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for the Northern Sportive Lemur is High. However, while this recovery is biologically and ecologically possible, it will require a large-scale coordinated effort.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Fen Orchid has a Species Recovery Score of 89% (Slightly Depleted) as it is Functional in four of its six biogeographic regions and Viable but not Functional in the remaining two. In regions where the species is Functional, natural geomorphological and epizoochorous processes sustain active metapopulation dynamics, and the species is not at risk of extirpation. In the North European Palearctic region, conservation efforts have driven recovery in many areas, including the rediscovery of the species in Bulgaria at restored sites. Without these actions, the species would likely not be Functional in this region. However, in other areas, conservation efforts have not significantly influenced its status, resulting in a Low Conservation Legacy. If current conservation measures continue, the species is expected to maintain its current status across all spatial units (Zero Conservation Gain). However, if conservation efforts were to cease, the species would likely lose its Functional status in the North European Palearctic region within the next decade (Low Conservation Dependence). In the long term, identifying and targeting non-Functional subpopulations with conservation actions, such as landscape restoration and reintroductions, could improve the Species Recovery Score to 95%, a 6% increase from the current score (Low Recovery Potential). However, achieving full functionality in the North Asian Palearctic Offshore Islands may prove challenging due to rapid development in the region.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Himalayan Monal has a Species Recovery Score of 58% (Moderately Depleted) because it is declining across its range, leaving it Viable in three spatial units and Present in the fourth. Nonetheless, there is a Medium Conservation Legacy; without the existence of protected areas, it is expected that the species would only be Viable in one spatial unit today, bringing the Recovery Score to 41%. The species' Conservation Gain is Indeterminate, but it has a Medium Conservation Dependence: if protected areas were to be degazetted, the species is expected to reduce its Recovery Score to 41% within 10 years. Finally, it would be feasible, with sustained and heightened conservation efforts, to restore the species to functionality across its range (a score of 100%). This gives the species a High Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Eurasian Otter's Species Recovery Score of 41% (Largely Depleted) is due to large declines since the 1950s as a result of hunting and habitat loss. The Eurasian Otter has an Indeterminate Conservation Legacy, meaning that it is difficult to measure the impact of past conservation; however, the best estimate this that legal protection has resulted in a higher score today than it would have had otherwise. There is also Indeterminate Conservation Dependence, meaning it is unclear how the score would change over the next 10 years if conservation stopped. However, the Eurasian Otter has a Low Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, if conservation continues as planned, it is expected that the species' score could increase from 41% to 43%. Finally, within 100 years, the Recovery Potential is also Indeterminate, as climate change is predicted to increase available habitat in some areas and decrease it in others.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 22% (Largely Depleted) is due to the Iberian Lynx being Absent in two of its six spatial units, and Present but not Functional in the remaining four. Despite its depleted state, the species has a High Conservation Legacy; measures such as area protection, reintroductions, poaching prevention, road kill mitigation, and genetic management have reversed population declines and prevented likely extinction. Continuation of these measures, as well as planned reintroductions to spatial units in which the species is currently Absent, are expected to double the Recovery Score in 10 years: a Medium Conservation Gain. If all conservation were to stop, declines would resume and the species would probably be extirpated from the East Spain spatial unit within 10 years, reducing the Recovery Score to 16%. However, populations would persist in at least three spatial units in this timeframe, so the Conservation Dependence is Low. Enough suitable habitat remains that the species could reach Fully Recovered status in 100 years, assuming conservation efforts continue with maximum efficacy. There is some uncertainty in this prediction, as the possibility of multiple disease outbreaks in European Rabbits (the species' main prey item) could hamper progress, but the Recovery Potential remains High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Large-antlered Muntjac has a Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) because remnant populations are small and low-density, and the species is undergoing declines in all three spatial units from which it is known. Area protection has mitigated loss and degradation of habitat, preventing likely extirpation of the species from one of the spatial units. The impact of protection has been less decisive in the other two units, as they contain forests that are large and remote enough that they probably would not have been totally cleared if they were not protected. Thus, the species has a Low Conservation Legacy. However, it has a High Conservation Dependence, because cessation of area protection and enforcement against poaching would likely reduce the Recovery Score to 5% within 10 years. Given that short-term conservation of this species is focussed on mitigating threats and preventing declines – which is an essential starting point to facilitating long-term recovery – the Conservation Gain over the next 10 years is predicted to be Zero. In 100 years, however, this species' recovery status has the potential to improve dramatically. This will require consolidation of current protective measures, complemented by well-planned ex situ breeding and translocation programs to boost populations. If such measures are funded and executed with maximum efficacy, the Recovery Score could increase more than five-fold to 80%, a High Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 17% (Critically Depleted) is due to massive forest loss across the Pink Pigeon's indigenous range. The Pink Pigeon has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, Pink Pigeons would almost certainly be extinct today. There is a Low Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that loss of restored ecological functionality would occur over a 10-year period, bringing the score to 12%. The Pink Pigeon has a Low Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, it is expected that the scope of threats facing the species will allow for only modest progress over that time scale (leading to a score of 22%). Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for Pink Pigeon to achieve ecological functionality in many of the spatial units where suitable habitat remains or could be restored, leading to a score of 44%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for Pink Pigeon is Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) is due to large-scale deforestation across the island of Hainan, resulting in the Hainan Gibbon being extirpated from the majority of its indigenous range, and now persisting in very small numbers in a single protected area. This species has a High Conservation Legacy as the protection of Bawangling National Nature Reserve allowed the persistence of the last wild population, and was crucial in preventing the extinction of this species. Given the small population size and 15-year generation length of this species, the remaining population is not expected to improve from Critically Endangered within the next 10 years, resulting in a Conservation Gain of Zero. However, given the demand for land, and the fact that gibbon species are hunted for food and traditional medicine, without continued protection, it is expected the Hainan Gibbon would be lost in 10 years, resulting in a High Conservation Dependence. As the remaining forest habitat is highly fragmented and the current population is very small, recovery of this species will be slow. Based on population viability analysis, it is expected that the current population could improve in 100 years, but it is still expected to be Endangered, resulting in a Low Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Royle's Pika has a Species Recovery Score of 83% (Slightly Depleted) because although it is widespread and found in large numbers, recent climate-related changes have caused this montane species to experience a genetic bottleneck across at least some parts of its range, which may reduce the species' fitness. Because no conservation actions have been carried out, or are planned, for the Royle's Pika, the species' Conservation Legacy, Conservation Dependence; and Conservation Gain are all Zero. However, within 100 years it would be possible for genetic restoration to recover the species to functionality across its range, leading to a score of 100%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for The Royle's Pika is Medium. However, climate change could threaten the achievement of that long-term recovery, and the confidence interval around the Recovery Potential estimate is wide.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 13% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Malagasy Giant Jumping Rat being Absent in one of its three spatial units, and Present as Critically Endangered and Endangered in the remaining two. Despite its Critically Depleted status, the species has a High Conservation Legacy because it is predicted that without conservation actions that halted habitat loss (i.e. site protection, site management, conservation payments, compliance and enforcement, and local policies and regulations) the species would have been lost. The most significant limiting factors for this species are habitat loss and degradation; consequently, the most impactful conservation actions are those related to habitat protection and restoration. However, within a 10-year time frame, the slow growth of the forest will limit population increase, as the habitat is not expected to support a Viable population. Without habitat protection measures it is expected that in the short-term future, steep population declines would likely result in either population extirpation or survival in low densities, which results in a High Conservation Dependence for the species. Over the next 10 years if conservation continues, the Conservation Gain is expected to be Zero; with no planned reintroductions, the populations in Ambadira and Kirindy are unlikely to change significantly over that time period. Finally, within the next 100 years, it is expected that increased human-induced pressures will negatively affect Malagasy Giant Jumping Rat subpopulations. Combined with the slow growth rate of the forest habitat the Giant Jumping Rat depends on, these pressures will hamper recovery and prevent the establishment of Viable populations. Consequently, the Recovery Potential is Low: it is unlikely that populations will recover beyond the Endangered category under criterion B1ab(iii), given the persistence of unavoidable drivers such as increased human population and climate change, which continue to lead to habitat degradation.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
Botsford's Leaf-litter Frog has an Indeterminate Species Recovery Score, as there is little to no information on the size or status of populations in two of the three spatial units that the species is thought to occur in. The species is protected within Hong Lien National Park, but because the current state of the species is so uncertain, it cannot be inferred what impact this protection has had in the past or could have in the future. Thus, all the Conservation Impact Metrics are also Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

Red List Authority Coordinator: Jennifer Luedtke (email: jluedtke@amphibians.org)
Newsletter: http://www.amphibians.org/froglog/

assessments.justification:
The Mountain Chicken has a Species Recovery Score of 5% (Critically Depleted) as it has been lost from the majority of islands on which it was once found, and is threatened (Present) only on Dominica, where it was driven to near-extinction by chytridiomycosis. Nonetheless, it has a High Conservation Legacy, because if a hunting ban and ban on importing mongooses had not been implemented on Dominica (the main non-chytrid threats to the species), the Mountain Chicken would almost certainly be extinct today. Nonetheless, if these actions stopped, the species could easily go extinct within 10 years (High Conservation Dependence). The remaining individuals may have a genetic resistance to chytrid (though this needs to be confirmed), and if chytrid control measures are put in place then this pool of individuals could be used for reintroductions to Montserrat within 10 years, bringing the Recovery Score to 10% (Low Conservation Gain). Nonetheless, this potential genetic basis for resistance, combined with control of invasive mammals on the islands of its indigenous range, could allow for the species to recover to 43% within 100 years (High Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Hudson, M.A., Cunningham, A.A. & Stephenson, P.J.

assessments.justification:
The Blood Pheasant has a Species Recovery Score of 60% (Moderately Depleted) because it is assessed as Viable but not Functional in four of its five indigenous range states. Most of these nations provide formal protections for the species or its habitat, with conservation efforts in India and Nepal specifically targeting pheasants. Without these measures to date, the species would face accelerated declines due to unchecked hunting and habitat loss (a Medium Conservation Legacy). If conservation efforts were to cease now, it is predicted that the species would lose its Viable status in all but one range state within 10 years, though it would not face extirpation in any country during this time (a Medium Conservation Dependence). Promising community conservation projects in Arunachal Pradesh, India, are expected to halt local declines, but overall range-wide declines are likely to persist over the next decade (a Low Conservation Gain). A significant portion of the species' indigenous habitat remains intact or is restorable; with maximum conservation efforts over the next 100 years, the species could recover to Functional status in at least two, and potentially more, of its indigenous range countries (a Medium Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 13% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Arabian Leopard being most likely Absent in three of its five spatial units, and most likely Present in the remaining two – considered threatened due to small population size. Despite its depleted state the subspecies has a High Conservation Legacy; measures such as protected areas, legislation banning killing of the Arabian Leopard, and livestock compensation programmes have slowed population declines and prevented potential extinction. Continuation of these measures, as well as successful ex situ breeding programmes and reintroductions, are expected to double the Recovery Score in 10 years: a Medium Conservation Gain. If all conservation were to stop, declines would continue and intensify, and in the worst-case scenario the Arabian Leopard could be Extinct in 10 years' time. However, due to the short timeframe it is most likely that in the next 10 years the subspecies would remain in the two spatial units where it is currently Present, albeit at reduced levels: Conservation Dependence is assessed as Zero. In the next 100 years we see High Recovery Potential; although the future is uncertain, if all plausible conservation measures are applied (e.g. strengthening the ex situ breeding programme, protected areas, and successful reintroductions) in 100 years the Arabian Leopard could be Present in all spatial units, most likely Functional in two spatial units, and in a best-case scenario could be Functional across the indigenous range (Fully Recovered). Conservation efforts have been, and will continue to be, crucial in preventing extinction of the Arabian Leopard. Although the subspecies still faces an uncertain future, with continued and intensified long-term conservation efforts there is great potential for the recovery of this Critically Endangered and Critically Depleted subspecies.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The African Leopard has a Species Recovery Score of 27% (Largely Depleted) because it has been extirpated from one of the spatial units in which it was historically found, and is Present but not Viable in the remaining four. Without conservation action to date—namely, protected areas and anti-poaching enforcement—it is likely that the subspecies would have disappeared from an additional spatial unit, though it would probably still be Present in the other three (a Low Conservation Legacy). Continuation of these measures, and the implementation of new measures including several national and regional conservation action plans, is expected to benefit the subspecies. However, the scope and severity of threats will probably not be abated sufficiently for the state of any spatial unit to improve short-term (Zero Conservation Gain). If all conservation were to stop, threats such as habitat loss, hunting, and illegal trade would accelerate, causing the leopard to vanish from many sites that it is currently found in. The categories used in this assessment (Absent, Present, Viable, Functional) are not sensitive enough to capture these losses at the spatial unit level, so the Conservation Dependence is Zero, but it is important to emphasise the necessity of continuing and improving conservation efforts. In 100 years, it would be possible to reintroduce the species to Northern Africa, where it is currently Absent. However, even with maximum conservation effort, restoring Viable spatial unit populations will be challenging due to projected climate-induced habitat loss and human population growth. Therefore, while the subspecies does have Recovery Potential, it is Low.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
Partula rosea has a Species Recovery Score of 0% due to its Extinct in the Wild (EW) status. As a result, its Conservation Legacy and Dependence are both assessed as Zero. While previous reintroduction efforts were unsuccessful, it has been proposed that experimental releases be conducted to test the species' survival under different conditions. If these trials prove more successful, P. rosea should, in theory, be relatively well protected from invasive predatory flatworm Platydemus manokwari, given its association with the canopy. Successful trials could lead to the establishment of a population on Huahine Nui within the next decade, reversing the species EW status: a High Conservation Gain. Once re-established on Huahine Nui, reintroductions could extend to Huahine Iti, the only other island within its indigenous range. With captive populations growing rapidly, large-scale releases could be feasible over the next century, indicating a High Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Pearce-Kelly, P., Gerlach, J. & Aberdeen, S.

assessments.justification:
Partula taeniata has a Species Recovery Score of 25% (Largely Depleted) because it remains at very high risk of extinction and is not ecologically Functional within its sole known spatial unit. Before conservation efforts began, the species had persisted despite years of predation by two invasive predators: the snail Euglandina rosea and the flatworm Platydemus manokwari. This suggests that even in the absence of conservation, the species would likely still exist today. However, translocations have successfully re-established one previously extirpated subpopulation, demonstrating a Low but significant Conservation Legacy. While these translocations have been effective and are set to continue, they are not occurring at a scale that would significantly improve the species' status within the next decade, resulting in a Zero Conservation Gain. The reintroduced subpopulations have now reached a stable stage where reinforcement is no longer necessary, meaning that even if conservation efforts ceased, they would likely persist at their current status – the species is therefore assessed as having Zero Conservation Dependence. In the long term, it is believed that this species could be restored to Functional population densities. Since mitigating the threat of predation by Platydemus manokwari is impossible, the species' survival depends on establishing stable subpopulations capable of withstanding some level of predation. Through continued research, captive breeding, and release, the initial focus will be on increasing individual numbers at release sites. This could eventually expand the species' range through additional releases, creating more resilient subpopulations. The species is already close to having re-established sufficiently that wild subpopulations could serve as sources for future translocations, significantly enhancing the potential for range expansion. Therefore, its Recovery Potential is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Pearce-Kelly, P., Gerlach, J. & Aberdeen, S.

assessments.justification:
Partula tohiveana has a Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) as it is not Functional and is at an extremely high risk of extinction in the sole spatial unit encompassing its indigenous range. The species was declared Extinct in the Wild following the introduction of predatory Euglandina rosea in 1977, but reintroduction efforts have successfully re-established a wild population. Without conservation action, P. tohiveana would not exist in the wild, nor would a captive population exist, indicating a High Conservation Legacy. The species action plan includes ongoing yearly releases of captive-bred individuals to reinforce the existing population and establish new subpopulations. While these efforts will boost the population, they are not expected to improve its Red List status beyond what would occur through wild reproduction of individuals released as part of the current reintroduction programme (Zero Conservation Gain). If the current reintroduction programme was stopped short of completion, the population would continue to grow through wild breeding, though at a significantly slower rate than under a business-as-usual scenario where the current reintroduction programme finished and no further releases were carried out (Low Conservation Dependence). In the long term, with continued releases and successful natural reproduction, the species is expected to achieve Functional status across much of its indigenous range, leading to a High Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Gerlach, J., Pearce-Kelly, P. & Aberdeen, S.

assessments.justification:
Pronk's Gecko (Phelsuma pronki) has a Species Recovery Score of 8% (Critically Depleted) as it has been extirpated from three of the four spatial units within its indigenous range and is Present but not Viable in the remaining one. Without the designation of protected areas in Mangabe and Anjozorobe, these strongholds would have experienced significant deforestation, leaving the remnant population in an even more precarious state. However, the species can tolerate some disturbance and persists in two unprotected forest fragments (Ambatovy mining area and Andramasina). This suggests that even in the absence of conservation efforts, it would likely survive in at least one spatial unit, though in a highly depleted state (Zero Conservation Legacy). Deforestation rates are accelerating across Madagascar, and despite existing protections, the species continues to face illegal habitat destruction. However, due to its resilience, it would likely persist—albeit in a more degraded state—even if conservation efforts ceased (Zero Conservation Dependence). A local conservation organisation is actively implementing a range of interventions in areas where the species remains, including community education and engagement, training in more sustainable and higher-yielding farming methods, recruitment of rangers from local communities, and connectivity restoration through corridor planting. With increasing adoption of sustainable farming techniques, population declines in this unit appear to be slowing and could stabilise within the next decade, making it Viable. However, there are currently no plans for reintroductions to areas where the species has been extirpated, resulting in a Low Conservation Gain. In the long term, conservationists should focus on restoring habitat connectivity through reforestation, expanding education programs, and improving habitat management. With these actions, combined with reintroductions to extirpated areas, the species could become Viable in all spatial units over the next century (a High Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Snake and Lizard Red List Authority

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 8% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Niger Delta Red Colobus being Critically Endangered in one of its two spatial units and Absent in the other, both as a result of recent severe population declines. It has a High Conservation Legacy, since it is likely that without systematic conservation actions related to education, forest management and rangers in the Western spatial unit, the species would now be extinct. There is a High Conservation Dependence because without conservation interventions to protect the species' habitat, it is expected to disappear due to habitat degradation and deforestation. The Conservation Gain is Zero for the species, given that within a 10-year period, there are no conservation plans for the species in the Eastern spatial unit, and in the Western spatial unit education programmes, forest management and training of rangers are expected to maintain population stability. Nonetheless, the Niger Delta Red Colobus has a High Recovery Potential, because even though recovery in the Eastern spatial unit is unlikely given severe habitat degradation, in the Western spatial unit it is expected that with increased habitat protection and community engagement, populations could recover to a Viable state.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Zanzibar Red Colobus has a Species Recovery Score of 20% (Critically Depleted) because it has been extirpated from coastal Tanzania, and persists in a threatened and depleted state on the island on Unguja. Conservation Legacy is High for this species; without protected areas, much of the species' forest habitat would have been cleared, fragmented, or degraded by now (as has been the case in non-protected areas) and the Recovery Score would be less than half of what it is today. The species' Conservation Dependence is Low; while ongoing protection is critical to the persistence of remnant populations, the consequences of revoking protection would not be fully realised in the 10-year timeframe over which Dependence is measured. Similarly, the expected positive outcome of planned conservation measures – namely, the designation of new protected areas – will not come to fruition within 10 years, so Conservation Gain is Zero. Long-term, however, it would be feasible to establish Functional populations in South Unguja. This would require forest restoration with a focus on improving connectivity. Because of this possibility, the species has a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Banded Wobbegong's Species Recovery Score of 100% (Fully Recovered) is due to the introduction of fishing restrictions in spatial units where it was previously threatened. The Banded Wobbegong has a Medium Conservation Legacy; if not for the implementation of fishing regulations, the species would likely still be threatened in two of its four spatial units. There is also a Medium Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species could become non-functional in these spatial units over a 10-year period, bringing the score to 83%. The Banded Wobbegong has a Conservation Gain of Zero; the species is already considered Fully Recovered. Finally, over the next 100 years this success is expected to continue and climate change is not considered a threat to this species, making the Recovery Potential for the Banded Wobbegong also Zero.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
Partula hehe has a Species Recovery Score of 0% because it is Extinct in the Wild (EW). Consequently, its Conservation Legacy and Dependence Scores are also Zero. However, it has a High predicted Conservation Gain, as reintroductions are planned in coming years that could reverse the species' EW status within a decade. While a previous reintroduction was unsuccessful due to the subsequent clearance of the release site for agriculture, early data from the project suggest that future efforts are likely to succeed. Long-term, with continued research, captive breeding, and release, it will be possible to increase the number of individuals at release sites, then there will be potential to expand the range with releases into further sites to create a Functional population. The species' Recovery Potential is therefore assessed as High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Pearce-Kelly, P., Gerlach, J. & Aberdeen, S.

assessments.justification:
The Polynesian Tree Snail has a Species Recovery Score of 83% (Slightly Depleted) because it is fully Functional on five of the seven islands within its indigenous range. On the remaining two islands, it is locally Endangered on Tubuai and Near Threatened on Tahiti due to historical population crashes caused by the introduced predator Euglandina rosea. However, the species is now believed to be increasing on Tahiti, having persisted despite E. rosea invasion due to its tolerance of dry, sunny habitats, such as forest edges, which provide a solar refuge where E. rosea cannot hunt for extended periods. A similar recovery is expected on Tubuai. Because this species is less vulnerable to invasive predators than other Partula species and because invasive predators are absent from most of its indigenous range, it has not been a priority for conservation action, and little intervention has been undertaken to date. As a result, its Conservation Legacy is assessed as Zero. Similarly, since no future conservation actions are planned, its Conservation Gain is also assessed as Zero. However, there is a risk that, without conservation measures, the invasive flatworm Platydemus manokwari could spread to islands where this species occurs. The potential impact remains uncertain, as P. manokwari has only been recorded on islands where Partula hyalina was already depleted, but it could lead to a population crash. Therefore, Conservation Dependence is assessed as Indeterminate. In the long term, given the species' apparent resilience to invasive predators, it is hoped that the populations on Tahiti and Tubuai will recover to Functional levels, even in the absence of major conservation efforts. Consequently, its Recovery Potential is assessed as Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Pearce-Kelly, P., Gerlach, J. & Aberdeen, S.

synonyms.name: Partula clara ssp. marmorata H.E. Crampton, 1916

assessments.justification:
Partula navigatoria has a Species Recovery Score of 0% because it is Extinct in the Wild (EW). Because of its EW status, its Conservation Legacy and Dependence are assessed as Zero. Attempts to reintroduce the species to its indigenous range on Raiatea Island have failed, and are unlikely to ever succeed, because of the presence of invasive predatory flatworm Platydemus manokwari. However, it may be possible to release the species into predator exclosures, and suitable sites for such exclosures have been identified on Moorea and Tahiti. An exclosure is being built on Moorea as of late 2023, and should be ready for trial releases in 2024–2025. If this succeeds, a population could be released and established within the next 10 years, reversing the species' EW status – a High Conservation Gain. While it is not possible to mitigate the threat of predation by P. manokwari, it is plausible that, within 100 years, Functional subpopulations of the species could be established in predator exclosures on Moorea and Tahiti. This reflects a High Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Pearce-Kelly, P., Gerlach, J. & Aberdeen, S.

assessments.justification:
Sterling's Toothed Toad has a Species Recovery Score of 22% (Largely Depleted) because there are probably very few individuals left, the result of habitat degradation associated with a recent surge in tourism in the species' indigenous range. The protection of habitat within national parks and a nature reserve have likely been beneficial to the species, but because of uncertainty in both its current state and extent to which protection has impacted it, Conservation Legacy is Indeterminate. Conservation Gain and Dependence are Indeterminate for the same reason. However, Recovery Potential is High, as much of the species' habitat is still intact and it would be feasible to restore Functional populations.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

Newsletter: http://www.amphibians.org/froglog/

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 30% (Largely Depleted) is due to the Lion being most likely Absent in two of its ten spatial units, most likely Viable in one spatial unit, and most likely Present in the remaining seven. Despite its depleted state the species has a High Conservation Legacy; in the absence of conservation actions, notably protected areas and legal protections, the Lion would have faced even greater declines across its range. This would most likely have resulted in the one spatial unit which is currently Viable being classed as Present due to declines, and extirpation of the species from four spatial units where it is currently Present. Conservation Gain is Zero; even with continued and planned conservation actions, the next ten years is too short a timeframe to expect significant recovery given the biological limitations of the species, although the current recovery status is expected to be maintained. However, Conservation Dependence is Medium; if all conservation actions were to stop, population declines would continue and intensify across the range, and in the next ten years the Lion would be extirpated from three spatial units where it is currently Present. In the next 100 years the Lion faces an uncertain future. If all plausible conservation measures could be applied with maximum efficacy (e.g. establishment of new protected areas, maintenance of existing protected areas, and reintroductions) then in a best-case scenario – considering an optimistic scenario for climate change and human demographic shifts – Lions could be Present across all spatial units and even Viable in eight out of ten spatial units in 100 years. However, even in this most optimistic scenario it is not likely for the Lion to reach the Functional state in any spatial unit due to irreversible anthropogenic impacts (e.g. habitat conversion) limiting recovery of the Lion across its indigenous range. Other factors beyond the control of conservation (e.g. climate change, terrorism and political instability, and human demographic shifts) could also limit Lion recovery. In a worst-case scenario, even with all plausible conservation actions in place, we could see extirpation from one spatial unit which is currently assessed as Present, as well as continued and intensified threats across the other spatial units within the next 100 years. This uncertainty is captured by the Low Recovery Potential, which highlights the need for continued and intensified conservation efforts to enable both Lion survival and recovery in the face of the great challenges presented by ongoing and potential emergent threats in the next 100 years.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
