assessments.justification:
Spengler's Freshwater Mussel has a Species Recovery Score of 20% (Critically Depleted) because it is Absent from five of the 10 drainage basins that make up its indigenous range, Present (but not Viable) in four, and Viable (but not Functional) in one. Some subpopulations are protected under the Habitat Directive of the Bern Convention, and there are species action plans in place in France and Spain. Furthermore, several of the basins in which the species is found are protected within Natura 2000 sites. Without these conservation measures, it is estimated that the species would be Absent from eight of its indigenous basins, reflecting a High Conservation Legacy. The subpopulations of the Loire, Garonne, and Ardour basins are currently very small (<500 individuals each). If conservation efforts stopped, these subpopulations would likely disappear within 10 years due to their high fragmentation and small sizes, which increase the likelihood of stochastic events leading to extirpation. Thus, the species' Conservation Dependence is assessed as High. However, if current measures continue, all basins are expected to retain their current status (Zero Conservation Gain). Long-term, conservationists should focus on protecting host fish species, removing threats, and expanding protected areas. There are currently no aspirations to reintroduce the species to basins where it has been extirpated, as efforts would be best directed toward improving existing subpopulations. An exception is the Seine, where reintroductions would be feasible and desirable, as extirpation is believed to have been relatively recent in this basin. Given the potential to enhance existing subpopulations and potentially reintroduce the species to the Seine, Recovery Potential is assessed as Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Koklass Pheasant has a Species Recovery Score of 58% (Moderately Depleted) because it is assessed as Viable but not Functional in all of its indigenous range states apart from Nepal, where it is Present but not Viable. Although most of the countries have formal protections in place for the species and/or its habitat, the degree to which these benefit the species is uncertain, as enforcement is inconsistent and there are minimal data on the species' state in China, Pakistan, and Afghanistan. Thus, Conservation Legacy and Dependence are Indeterminate. No new conservation measures for the next 10 years are known, but continuation of existing measures should allow the species to maintain its current state. The expected Conservation Gain is therefore Zero. More research is required to determine the species' status, threats, and necessary conservation actions in data deficient parts of the indigenous range; until more is known, the Recovery Potential will remain Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Chinstrap Penguin has a Species Recovery Score of 80% (Moderately Depleted). The primary conservation actions for this species have included regulation of the fisheries of their prey, but the species' score is not expected to be different today in the absence of this action (Conservation Legacy of Zero), though there is uncertainty around this estimate. Over the next 10 years, the best estimate is that the species would decline if conservation action stopped, but the future impact of conservation actions is hard to estimate precisely given that climate change is predicted to cause declines in species status over the same period; therefore, a dynamic baseline was used, but even so Conservation Dependence and Gain are both Indeterminate. Finally, in 100 years, due to climate change the most optimistic estimate is that the species will have declined to a Recovery Score of 60%, meaning that the Recovery Potential is Negative.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Boynton Oak has a Species Recovery Score of 30% (Largely Depleted) because it is Present but not Viable in eight of its nine spatial units, and presumed Absent in the ninth. The Conservation Impact Metrics have not yet been assessed for this species.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Thompson, P., Good, K., Byrne, A. & Jerome, D.

assessments.justification:
Encino Arroyero's Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) is due to low recruitment and an age structure skewed toward very old individuals, preventing the species from being Viable in any of its spatial units (instead, it is Present in all of them). Encino Arroyero has a Conservation Legacy of Zero due to the species' extremely long generation time and continued threats, even within protected areas. Because of the possible states that can be assigned in the Green Status assessment, there is also Zero Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species would indeed decline majorly over a 10-year period, but likely some individuals would remain, which would mean the species was still Present in all of its spatial units. Encino Arroyero has a Medium Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, if proposed bans on cutting down these trees are implemented, and planned seedling planting is carried out, it is expected that the species could become Viable in some of its spatial units, leading to a score of 44%. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for Encino Arroyero to become Functional in two spatial units and Viable in most, leading to a score of 77%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for Encino Arroyero is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Species Recovery Score of 27% (Largely Depleted) is due to the Southern Mountain Yellow-legged Frog being Absent in one spatial unit and Present (but not Viable or Functional) in the rest. Furthermore, extant subpopulations are suffering from high mortality caused by infection with chytrid fungus. Despite its depleted state, the species has a Medium Conservation Legacy; without conservation measures like ex situ breeding, reintroduction, and predator barriers, the species is expected to have disappeared in two more spatial units. Despite ongoing conservation actions (including research, actions to combat chytrid fungus, habitat restoration, reintroduction efforts, and predator management), it is unlikely that these measures will change the status of the any Southern Mountain Yellow-legged Frog spatial units to Viable within the next 10 years, so the Southern Yellow-legged Frog's Conservation Gain is Zero. Nonetheless, given that the species persists in few localities, without ex situ breeding and reintroduction efforts its is likely that extant subpopulations would be more vulnerable to population crashes caused by chytrid infections and stochastic events (like droughts and fires); therefore the Conservation Dependence is Medium. In the long term, captive breeding and reintroduction efforts are expected to increase population numbers, and chytrid management and research are anticipated to positively impact species survival; with population and genetic management, it would be possible for many spatial units to reach a Viable state within 100 years. However, the species is unlikely to reach a Functional state in any spatial units due to the combined threats and stressors of introduced fish, disease-induced mortality, habitat degradation and climate change; therefore, the species' Recovery Potential is Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Whale Shark's Species Recovery Score of 29% (Largely Depleted) is due to the species being threatened across its range because of declines in abundance. The Whale Shark has a Low Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, the Whale Shark would have a score of 25%, as it is expected that the closure of some targeted fisheries in two spatial units helped reduce the species' decline there. There is a Low Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that resumed high levels of bycatch could become an issue in one spatial unit over a 10-year period, bringing the score to 27%. The Whale Shark has a Medium Conservation Gain; the species has a long generation time, limiting the speed at which it can show recovery, but within a 10-year period it is expected that a reduction in targeted fishing, and bycatch mitigation in gillnet and purse-seine fisheries, will allow populations to stabilize, albeit at a low level, leading to a score of 55%. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for The Whale Shark to Fully Recover; climate shifts, and potential effects on plankton productivity, are not expected to limit Whale Shark habitat availability. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for The Whale Shark is High, but achieving this will required concerted and sustained effort.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Sardinian Currant's Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) is due to the fact that this species, which has only ever existed in one spatial unit, is not currently Viable. The Sardinian Currant has a Conservation Legacy and Conservation Gain of Zero; past attempts to bolster the wild population with individuals from ex situ populations have not been successful, and while attempts continue, it is unclear whether they will be able to restore a Viable population within 10 years, given ongoing threats from human disturbance and grazing animals. Given these threats, there is a High Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species would likely go extinct over a 10-year period. Finally, with effective protection and successful translocations, within 100 years it would be possible for the Sardinian Currant to become Fully Recovered. However, this future is uncertain, especially because the relict population is vulnerable to extinction via stochastic events, which are expected to increase in frequency with climate change. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for Sardinian Currant is Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Fenu, G., Cogoni, D. & Bacchetta, G.

assessments.justification:
The Bonnethead Shark's Species Recovery Score of 44% (Largely Depleted) reflects that while the species is Viable in one of its three spatial units, it is not ecologically Functional; in the other two spatial units, the species is threatened and therefore Present (not Viable). The Bonnethead Shark has a High Conservation Legacy; without past fisheries management, the Bonnethead Shark would have a score of 11%, due to expected extirpation in two spatial units and loss of viability in the third. There is a High Conservation Dependence; if management were to stop, it is expected that within a 10-year period, the score could drop to 11%. The Bonnethead Shark has a Medium Conservation Gain; regulation is expected to have the most effect in the spatial unit that is currently Viable, allowing the species to become Functional there and contributing to an overall score of 55%. Finally, the species breeds extremely quickly, so if effective fisheries management were implemented range-wide, within 100 years the species could easily be Viable in all spatial units, and Functional in one, for an overall score of 77%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for the Bonnethead Shark is Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Estuarine Pipefish has a Species Recovery Score of 13% (Critically Depleted) because it is locally extinct in three of its five indigenous estuaries, and threatened in in the other two. Storm-induced flooding, which was probably the cause of the species' extirpation from two of the extinct estuaries, poses an ongoing threat that could drive either of the remaining populations to Critically Endangered or Extinct status in a short period of time. While the species and its habitat are legally protected, these laws are weakly enforced and unlikely to have had a notable impact on the state of the population (Zero Conservation Legacy). As such, the species persistence is unlikely to depend on whether or not these laws are in place (Zero Conservation Dependence). However, a recovery action strategy has been developed for the species that involves research, education, habitat protection, ex situ breeding, and reintroduction to the extirpated estuaries. No reintroductions are due to take place in the next decade, and flooding will remain a pervasive threat, so the expected short-term Conservation Gain is Zero; but in the next century, re-establishment of the extinct populations (with ex situ 'back up' populations maintained in case of flooding) could improve the Species Recovery Score to 33%. Thus, the Recovery Potential is Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Claassens, L., Stephenson, P.J. & Whitfield, A.

assessments.justification:
Blyth's Tragopan has a Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) because it is assessed as Present but not Viable in all its indigenous range countries. Although most of the countries have formal protections in place for both the species and its habitat, the degree to which these benefit the species is uncertain, as enforcement is inconsistent and there are minimal data on the species' state in Bhutan and China. Thus, Conservation Legacy and Dependence are Indeterminate. While there is a promising community conservation project in Nagaland, India, this will only improve the species' status locally. In the rest of its indigenous range, there are no known conservation measures planned beyond the aforementioned formal protections. The expected Conservation Gain globally is therefore Zero. More research is required to determine the species' status, threats, and necessary conservation actions in data deficient parts of the indigenous range; until more is known, the Recovery Potential will remain Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Western Tragopan has a Species Recovery Score of 35% (Largely Depleted). However, without the legal protection it has received, it is estimated that the Recovery Score would fall by 10% today to 25%, giving it a Low Conservation Legacy (relative to the current score). While the relatively slow-growing species is not expected to improve in score over the next 10 years (Conservation Gain of Zero), if conservation actions were to stop, over that same time frame the species' Recovery Score is predicted to fall by 10% (Low Conservation Dependence, relative to current score). Over 100 years, it would be possible to restore the species to viability throughout its range, leading to a score of 65% (Medium Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
Trechus terrabravensis has a Species Recovery Score of 83% (Slightly Depleted). The species is endemic to Ilha Terceira. While much forest has been cleared on the island, and protected areas established in response, the species is a habitat specialist restricted to inaccessible areas and it is unclear how much habitat has been lost to human development; therefore, the Conservation Legacy is Indeterminate. The species has a High Conservation Dependence; without continued management of invasive plants, the species' Recovery Score is expected to decrease to 25% over the next 10 years. However, continued removal of invasive plants and creation of corridors is expected to benefit the species in future, with maximum expected recovery to 91% achievable within the next 10 years, giving the species a Low Conservation Gain and Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

Raffles' Banded Langur has a Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) as it persists in very small, often severely fragmented subpopulations across all three of the spatial units within its indigenous range. The establishment of the Raffles' Banded Langur Working Group and a Species Action Plan has driven ongoing conservation efforts for the species. These efforts have included roadkill mitigation measures like rope bridges, awareness-raising initiatives, improved research efforts, and long-standing habitat protection. Without these actions, the species would likely have been extirpated from one of the spatial units by now (a Low Conservation Legacy).

The 'Presbytis Conservation Action Plan 2024–2034' outlines plans to restore habitat connectivity through tree planting and rope bridge construction (Ang et al. 2024), which will complement the Pahang 30x30 initiative. In combination with continued area protection and the implementation of the Species Action Plan, these measures are expected to increase the size and connectivity of subpopulations over the next decade. However, the species will still face a very high risk of extinction (the predicted Conservation Gain is Low).

If conservation efforts were to cease, habitat destruction and fragmentation would accelerate due to expanding plantations and urban sprawl, likely leading to the rapid extirpation of the remaining subpopulations, as has occurred in unprotected former range areas (High Conservation Dependence).

Long-term, conservationists should aim to improve the species' genetic viability through translocations. Combined with habitat protection and restoration efforts, this offers the potential for the species to become Viable or Functional across all its spatial units (High Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Laurocho has a Species Recovery Score of 42% (Largely Depleted) because it has been permanently extirpated from São Miguel Island, and persists in a depleted state on Pico Island. Of the three subpopulations on Pico, one is Present (but non-Viable) and two are Viable (but non-Functional). However, without the implementation of cattle exclusion zones and invasive plant control by the 'LIFE BEETLES and LIFE IP AZORES NATURA' projects, the species' habitat would be in a more degraded state and none of the subpopulations would be Viable (representing a Medium Conservation Legacy). Likewise, if these measures were to stop now, all the subpopulations would revert to being non-Viable within 10 years (Medium Conservation Dependence). Thankfully, conservation is expected to continue improving habitat quality, which should allow all extant subpopulations to achieve Viable status by 2033 (a Low Conservation Gain).

Despite conservation efforts, viability cannot be maintained long-term, as climate-induced dryness is expected decrease habitat suitability for the species over the course of the next 100 years. This is predicted to decrease the Recovery Score from 42% to 25%, meaning the species has a Negative Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Ferreira, M.T., Oyarzabal, G. & Cygan, M.G.W.

assessments.justification:
The Spiky Yellow Woodlouse (Pseudolaureola atlantica) has a Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) because it is neither Viable nor Functional in its sole known spatial unit. Its cloud forest habitat has declined dramatically, from 600 hectares historically to just 16 hectares today. The species has a High Conservation Legacy, as without the protection of St Helena Island National Park, its last fragment of habitat would have been lost, leading to extinction. It also has a High Conservation Dependence, as removal of the park's protected status would result in rapid destruction of this final habitat fragment, mirroring the loss of the rest of its historical range. Dutton et al. (2021) proposed a comprehensive conservation action plan, including habitat restoration, threat mitigation, and further research on the species' biology. However, even with these efforts, ongoing population declines and the extremely limited habitat extent are likely to keep the species within the Critically Endangered category in the short term, indicating a Conservation Gain score of Zero. Despite these challenges, sustained and long-term conservation efforts could eventually stabilise or reverse declines, potentially leading to a Least Concern status in the long-term future. Therefore, the species has a High Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Sherwood, D., Fowler, L. & Wilkins, V.L.

assessments.justification:
The Socotra Freshwater Crab has a Species Recovery Score of 60% (Moderately Depleted), with one spatial unit considered fully Functional, three classified as Viable (though with considerable uncertainty), and one where the species is Absent. To date, the species has not benefited from conservation efforts, resulting in a Conservation Legacy score of Zero. Plans are in place to enhance the protection of its aquatic habitat; however, due to uncertainty regarding the species' Current State in some spatial units and the likely impact of protection, both Conservation Gain and Conservation Dependence are assessed as Indeterminate. In the long term, safeguarding the species' habitat from degradation and reintroducing it to the locality where it is currently Absent could support the recovery of Viable or Functional spatial unit populations across its range. However, given the inherent uncertainty in both the species' Current State and long-term projections over the next 100 years, its Recovery Potential is also classified as Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
Cycas calcicola has a Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) because it is Present but not Viable in all four spatial units in which it has been recorded. While some areas benefit from area protection and habitat management, the impact of these measures on the species is likely to be limited. Current management activities are insufficient to address the threat posed by fire-promoting invasive grasses, with removal efforts unable to keep pace with their spread. Moreover, the species persists outside protected and managed areas, indicating it would still be Present without conservation interventions. The Conservation Legacy is therefore assessed as Zero.

There are no planned conservation actions likely to benefit the wild population of C. calcicola within the next 10 years beyond the limited impact of ongoing measures. Anyhow, the species' long generation time means any positive outcomes from conservation would take much longer than a decade to manifest. Consequently, the Conservation Gain and Conservation Dependence within this timeframe are also Zero.

Long-term conservation measures that could be feasible include better-resourced habitat management, reintroduction programmes, and the establishment of genetically representative assurance colonies. These actions could reverse declines and improve connectivity, enabling all spatial units to achieve Viable status, amounting to a Medium Recovery Potential. However, this estimate should be treated with caution, as low genetic diversity and the absence of a seed dispersal agent may limit the likelihood of success.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Cycad Specialist Group

Red List Authority Coordinator: De Wet Bosenberg (email: D.Bosenberg@sanbi.org.za)

assessments.justification:
Dianthus morisianus has a Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) as it is currently classified as Critically Endangered in the only spatial unit where it has been recorded. However, conservation efforts, including protective fencing and a translocation project, have greatly improved the species' prospects. Translocations have been highly successful, with demographic data indicating that the population is now stable. Without these conservation actions, the population would be smaller and in decline, and habitat degradation would be progressing at a faster rate. Despite these positive impacts, the Conservation Legacy remains Zero, as the species' status has not yet improved beyond Critically Endangered. If conservation were to cease, the population would likely remain stable for the next decade due to past translocation efforts, resulting in a Conservation Dependence score of Zero. Longer-term, however, unmitigated habitat degradation would lead to population decline, highlighting the need for continued habitat protection. With continuation of current conservation efforts, habitat degradation is expected to slow to a halt over the next decade. Combined with additional reintroductions, which could increase the population to over 1,000 mature individuals, the species is projected to improve to Least Concern by 2035—a High Conservation Gain. Demographic data suggest that, over 100 years, the population could expand and recolonise the dune system, provided its stable size distribution is maintained. This reflects a High Recovery Potential. Continued monitoring remains essential to ensure population stability.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Beira has a Species Recovery Score of 35% (Largely Depleted) because it is at a high risk of extinction in the only spatial unit in which is has been known to occur. There are no effective past, present, or planned conservation actions within the species' range, so the Conservation Legacy, Dependence, and Gain are all Zero. With significant conservation intervention, such as effective protected areas, stringent bans on hunting, and prohibition of tree cutting for charcoal or fodder, the species could recover significantly, but the extent to which recovery is feasible is uncertain. Therefore, the Recovery Potential is Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Asiatic Wild Ass has a Species Recovery Score of 40% (Largely Depleted) because one of its subspecies is extinct (Syrian Wild Ass Equus hemionus hemippus), two are Present but not Viable (Kulan E. h. kulan, and Onager E. h. onager), and two are Viable but not Functional (Indian Khur E. h. khur, and Gobi Khulan E. h. hemionus). However, without conservation measures such as legal protection, area protection, and reintroductions, it is likely that only the Gobi Khulan subspecies would be left today; the Conservation Legacy is High. Likewise, if all conservation were to stop, it is predicted that all subspecies apart from the Gobi Khulan would be extinct within 10 years. Thus, the species' Conservation Dependence is also High. If ongoing and planned reintroductions succeed, the Kulan and Onager could become Viable in 10 years' time; this represents a Medium Conservation Gain. Over the next 100 years, conservation actions such as improving protected areas, increasing enforcement against poaching, mitigating linear infrastructure construction, continuing reintroductions, and controlling invasive plants could raise its category to Moderately Depleted, representing a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 2% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Saint Lucia Racer being Absent from six of the seven spatial units, following extirpation from mainland Saint Lucia. Saint Lucia Racers remain on one small offshore island (Maria Major) where they are assessed as Critically Endangered due to the small population size. Despite its depleted state, the species has a High Conservation Legacy due to the importance of restricted access to Maria Major and strict biosecurity control and monitoring for invasive species protecting the last remaining population. Continuation of these measures are important to preserve the Maria Major population. In order to establish an additional wild population, a predator free mainland island is being established on Saint Lucia. It is expected that within 10 years time, a small population of Saint Lucia Racer will be established within the mainland island, but it will only be in the early stages, therefore still Critically Endangered, resulting in a Low Conservation Gain. Long-term it is expected that a Functional population of Saint Lucia Racer will establish within the mainland island, resulting in a High Recovery Potential, although the species will still be restricted to this fenced area on the mainland.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

Heuglin's Gazelle has a Species Recovery Score of 25% (Largely Depleted) because it is at a very high risk of extinction in the only spatial unit in which is has been known to occur. If there had been no past area protection and enforcement against poaching, it is estimated that the Recovery Score would be 10% worse today; a Low but significant Conservation Legacy. Likewise, if these measures were to stop now, the score would likely decrease by 10% in the next 10 years; the species' Conservation Dependence is Low. It is possible that some additional conservation actions will begin in the next 10 years, but these are unlikely to improve the species' status in this short timeframe; thus, Zero Conservation Gain is predicted. If an effective action plan is created and implemented, declines could be reversed and the population increased to the point that the species is no longer threatened with extinction. The species' Recovery Potential is therefore Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

Euterpe edulis has a Species Recovery Score of 50% (Largely Depleted) as it is Viable but not Functional in one of its biomes (the Cerrado) and Present but not Viable in the other (the Atlantic Rainforest). A key threat to the species in the Atlantic Rainforest is harvesting for palm heart. Without its illegalisation in Brazil in 2008 and the protection provided by designated conservation areas, the population would face a significantly higher risk of extirpation. In the Cerrado, palm heart harvesting is not a major threat, and the species is found exclusively in gallery forests, which are legally protected. Without this protection, the destruction of gallery forests would likely track the rapid deforestation of the broader Cerrado biome, making the population non-Viable. As a result, the Conservation Legacy is assessed as Medium. If conservation measures were to cease, a similar situation would unfold over the next decade, justifying a Medium Conservation Dependence. However, current conservation measures are expected to continue, helping both biome populations maintain their current status (Zero Conservation Gain). Looking ahead, the extent of climatically suitable habitat in the Atlantic Rainforest is expected to expand over the next century. Increasing protected area coverage, enforcing regulations against harvesting and deforestation, and implementing reintroduction and fruit management programmes could reverse population declines within this timeframe. Predicting the species' recovery potential in the Cerrado is more challenging due to limited data on its current distribution, status, and threats in this biome. While it is likely that the species could become Functional in much of the Cerrado—since gallery forests can persist despite agricultural expansion—uncertainties remain. Therefore, the species' Recovery Potential is considered Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Portela, R., Mendes, E.T.B., de Lima, T.M., Oda, G.A. & dos Santos, A.S.

assessments.justification:
Cuvier's Gazelle has a Species Recovery Score of 42% (Largely Depleted) as it remains Viable in only one of its three spatial units (Morocco–Western Sahara) while facing a likely risk of extinction in the other two (Tunisia and Algeria). In Morocco–Western Sahara, conservation measures such as a national strategy, captive breeding, and reintroduction programmes have been crucial in sustaining the population. Without these efforts, significant declines would be expected. Conversely, Algeria and Tunisia have seen little effective conservation action benefiting the species to date, resulting in a Low Conservation Legacy. If conservation efforts ceased today, the Morocco–Western Sahara population would likely become threatened with extinction within a decade due to its reliance on reintroductions. Meanwhile, the Algerian and Tunisian populations would likely maintain their current threatened status, as they have persisted this long with minimal conservation intervention. Thus, Conservation Dependence is assessed as Low. A conservation workshop held in Tunisia in 2016 resulted in the development of a strategy for recovering the species in the country, leading to some reintroductions. While these efforts have slightly increased the population, they have not yet improved its conservation status. However, the strategy is expected to enhance the Tunisian population's state over the next decade, reducing its extinction risk, though it will likely remain threatened. The Morocco–Western Sahara and Algerian populations are expected to maintain their current status over this timeframe. Therefore, the predicted Conservation Gain is Low. With conservation actions and plans already in place, there is hope for long-term improvement in the species' status. A small number of individuals are held in ex situ care, serving as a potential source for conservation translocations to areas lacking ongoing efforts. However, uncertainty regarding the species' status in Algeria and its potential for improvement means the Recovery Potential remains Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Slender-horned Gazelle has a Species Recovery Score of 13% (Critically Depleted) due to its extirpation from one, possibly two, of its historical spatial units and its very high risk of extinction in the remaining areas. The species persists in several protected areas, which have helped slow its decline; without them, its status in at least one spatial unit would likely be worse (a Low but significant Conservation Legacy). If these protected areas were removed, the species would likely be extirpated from the spatial unit where it is already close to (or possibly already) extinct, and its risk of extinction in the other unit would significantly increase within a decade due to unrestricted hunting (a High Conservation Dependence). However, over the next decade, several planned conservation actions aim to reverse the population decline. The 2020–2029 conservation framework outlines key priorities, including population surveys to assess its current status, anti-poaching measures, and enhancements to the captive population through improved management protocols and the construction of a new breeding facility in Tunisia—representing a Low but significant Conservation Gain. In the long term, feasibility studies for reintroductions could pave the way for the recovery of a Viable wild population within 100 years. Fewer than 100 Slender-horned Gazelles exist in captivity, with approximately 78 in the USA and 17 in Europe, providing a potential source for future reintroductions—resulting in a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

Speke's Gazelle has a Species Recovery Score of 25% (Largely Depleted) because it is at a very high risk of extinction in the only spatial unit in which is has been known to occur. There are no effective past, present, or planned conservation actions within the species' range, so the Conservation Legacy, Dependence, and Gain are all Zero. However, Recovery Potential is Medium, as the implementation of protected areas and translocations could reverse declines and secure a Viable (and potentially even partially Functional) population in the next 100 years.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Giant River Prawn has a Species Recovery Score of 100% (Non-Depleted) as it is a common species whose distribution and abundance are not assessed to have been significantly impacted by humans, despite its commercial use. No conservation actions have been taken for this species, and none are planned at this time, so the four Conservation Impact Metrics (Conservation Legacy, Conservation Dependence, Conservation Gain, and Recovery Potential) are all Zero.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Soemmerring's Gazelle has a Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) because, among its five indigenous range states, it is Viable in only one, Present but not Viable in three, and Absent in one. In Eritrea, where the species is Viable, strict prohibitions on gun ownership and hunting have played a key role in maintaining the population. In Ethiopia, effective protected areas provide some support, and without them, the population's status would likely be worse (though still Present). However, no conservation actions have benefited the species in its other range states, resulting in a Low Conservation Legacy. If conservation efforts were to stop now, the species' status might decline somewhat in Eritrea and Ethiopia but would remain unchanged in the other states where no conservation is currently in place—reflecting a Low Conservation Dependence. At present, no new conservation measures are planned, meaning the expected Conservation Gain is Zero. However, in the long term, if more effective protected areas are established, legal protections are better enforced, habitat is restored, and reintroductions are carried out, the species could become Viable in nearly all of its indigenous range states, giving it a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Species Recovery Score of 18% (Critically Depleted) is due to Bojer's Skink being Absent from nine of the 12 spatial units delineated. The loss of Bojer's Skink across much of its former range was due to the arrival of invasive predator species that led to extirpation. Bojer's Skink has a Low Conservation Legacy because it was able to persist in the presence of some non-native predators and even without past conservation actions, it is expected to have remained relatively undisturbed on two of the islands on which it is found, due to their remoteness and difficulty to access. However, due to the threat posed by invasive predators and the importance of past predator control in increasing the numbers on several islands, the Conservation Legacy score (8%) is close to the threshold for being considered a High Conservation Legacy (9%). Similarly, Conservation Dependence is assessed as Low due to the potential for this species to remain relatively undisturbed on two very difficult to access islands, but again the Conservation Dependence score (8%) is close to the threshold for being considered a High Conservation Dependence (9%). Conservation Gain is Zero as future actions in a 10-year time frame are not expected to change the species status on islands where the species has already been lost (due to invasive species) and short-term future conservation is expected to maintain current populations within spatial units. The Recovery Potential within 100 years is Low, as two of the three spatial unit where this species could be restored are already Functional. The aspiration is that in the future, the Southern Island spatial unit will become Functional, and that reintroductions to Flat Island and Gabriel Island, following the removal of shrews, will increase the proportion of the Northern Islands spatial unit that is Functional.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Cole, N., Ruhomaun, K., Seeneevassin, P., Tatayah, V. & Young, R.E.
