assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 13% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Menzbier's Marmot being Absent in on of the spatial units and Critically Endangered and Endangered in the other two, which reflects the species' extirpation from areas of its former range, restriction in extent of occurrence (EOO) and population decline. This species has a Conservation Legacy of Zero as to date, the main conservation action has been the establishment of protected areas. Despite this protection, there are still pressures of poaching and livestock grazing in the Talas Mountains areas and the population was lost from the Tajikistan and Kuraminskyi Ridge spatial unit, despite the establishment of a protected area. In addition, individuals have persisted outside protected areas in the Chatkal and Chimgan spatial unit, demonstrating that in the past they have not been completely reliant on habitat protection. The Conservation Dependence is Low (10%) because, whilst in one spatial unit the population is expected to decline from Endangered to Critically Endangered without continued conservation, the status of the Talas spatial unit is expected to improve from Critically Endangered to Vulnerable, even without continued conservation. This is because the large population decline in the previous three generations has now stabilised, and the population is expected to remain stable or increase due to a number of factors. Livestock grazing has stabilized and shows no immediate signs of expansion, and there are changing attitudes towards participation in hunting by younger herders, and a reduced reliance on dogs by herders, which posed a threat to Menzbier's Marmots. Conservation Gain is also Low (10%) because despite expected improvements in the next decade, this is partially attributed to conservation action, such as planned protected area expansion in Uzbekistan, but also partly due to the aforementioned attitudinal changes. Menzbier's Marmot has a Medium Recovery Potential (23%) because it is unlikely that the lost part of the range will be restored to support Menzbier's Marmot populations, and in other parts of the range, habitat loss induced by climate change is likely unavoidable, thus is expected to constrain the species full recovery. Human population growth and increased infrastructure and livestock to support it is expected in higher elevations, where the species range is likely to shift in response to climate change (as it is already being observed). However, with the expected expansion of protected areas it is likely that >50% of the species range will be protected and that currently fragmented subpopulations could reconnect.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Bykova, E., Esipov, A., Gazzard, A., Plakhov, K. & Sultangaziev, О.E.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Small Mammal Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Thomas Lacher (email: tlacher@tamu.edu) and Rosalind Kennerley (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Roslaind Kennedy (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)

assessments.justification:
The Dama Gazelle has a Species Recovery Score of 14% (Critically Depleted) because it is Present but not Viable in three of the seven spatial units that make up its indigenous range and Absent from the remaining four. In Niger and Chad, the species is protected within nature reserves, which may have helped mitigate some threats and slow declines, but not enough to impact the Recovery Score. Elsewhere, the wild population has received minimal conservation support, leading to a Conservation Legacy assessment of Zero.

Since the species has persisted with minimal conservation efforts, it would likely survive for the next decade even if conservation were to cease, resulting in a Zero Conservation Dependence Score. In most of its indigenous range, no additional conservation measures are planned for the near future; while Morocco and Tunisia have national strategies aiming to reintroduce the species, these efforts are unlikely to materialise within the next decade, leading to a predicted Conservation Gain of Zero.

However, in the long term, reintroductions are expected to take place in Morocco, Tunisia, and potentially other areas, which could feasibly restore the species to all currently unoccupied spatial units. Ensuring the success of these efforts will require controlling feral dogs and implementing anti-poaching measures. Given the feasibility of successful reintroductions, the Recovery Potential for the Dama Gazelle is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Species Recovery Score of 35% (Largely Depleted) is due to the species being threatened in the only spatial unit in which it is known to have occurred. Despite its depleted state, the species has a High Conservation Legacy; prior to the establishment of the first action plan, the species was Critically Endangered, and without concerted conservation action it would most likely have stayed this way (or, in a worst-case scenario, gone extinct). It is hoped that proposed measures to protect and enhance spoonbill habitat will slow the decline in habitat quality, but it is unlikely that these declines will be reversed within 10 years. Thus, the species will most likely retain its current threatened status, equating to Zero Conservation Gain. However, if all conservation were to stop, the progress made over the last decades would most likely be lost and the species' status would revert to Critically Endangered: it therefore has a High Conservation Dependence. Even though some habitat will be lost to development in the next 100 years, it would be possible (with dedicated planning and funding commitments) to protect enough of the species' range that the population could return to a Fully Recovered state. Because of this, the Recovery Potential is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Chan, S., Yu, Y., Cano Alonso, L.S. & Grace, M.K.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Pygmy Hog has a Species Recovery Score of 8% (Critically Depleted) as it has been extirpated from the majority of its indigenous range. However, without protected areas and reintroductions, the species would almost certainly be extinct today, resulting in a High Conservation Legacy. Over the next 10 years, if conservation stopped, the species is expected to become Absent in one spatial unit, decreasing the Recovery Score to 4% (Low Conservation Dependence); conversely, over the same time period, the species is likely to be reintroduced to another spatial unit, increasing the Recovery Score to 13% (Low Conservation Gain). In the long term, it would be possible to reintroduce the species in a handful of spatial units, and to establish a Functional population in one spatial unit, bringing the score to 29% (Medium Recovery Potential, relative to the current score).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Deka, P., Hudson, M.A., Das, D. & Kennerley, R.

assessments.justification:
Rhinoderma darwinii's Species Recovery Score of 17% (Critically Depleted) is due to the species having been extirpated in the majority of its indigenous range, and threatened in many of the pockets where it does remain. The species has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, it is expected that R. darwinii would be nearly extinct today, with a score of just 2%. There is a High Conservation Dependence; if species and habitat protection were to stop, it is expected that habitat loss and degradation would occur in many areas where the species remains over a 10-year period, bringing the score to 1%. Rhinoderma darwinii has a Conservation Gain of Zero; within a 10-year period it is expected that planned conservation actions, while beneficial, would primarily work to prevent further decline. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for R. darwinii to be reintroduced in some parts of the range where habitat remains or could be restored, and that it could be recovered to ecologically functional populations in parts of its range, leading to a score of 59%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for R. darwinii is High.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Crump, M., Grace, M.K. & Cygan, M.G.W.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Amphibian Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Chair: Ariadne Angulo (email: aangulo@amphibians.org)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Jennifer Luedtke (email: jluedtke@amphibians.org)
Newsletter: http://www.amphibians.org/froglog/

assessments.justification:
The American Mink has a Species Recovery Score of 69% (Moderately Depleted) because, across the spatial units covering its indigenous range, it is Present but not Viable in three, Viable but not Functional in five, and Functional in four. Harvest management has likely helped mitigate declines in some subspecies, and Neogale vison evergladensis and N. v. halilimnetes benefit from legal protection in some areas. However, the overall impact of these measures on the species' status is unclear, leading to an Indeterminate Conservation Legacy. For the same reason, it is uncertain what negative effects would result from removing these measures, making Conservation Dependence also Indeterminate. There is an action plan in place for N. v. evergladensis, which includes goals to expand its area of occupancy, mitigate threats, and enhance habitat quality. While this may improve the subspecies' status over the next 10 years, other subspecies are not expected to see substantial conservation benefits in this timeframe, resulting in a Low expected Conservation Gain. In the long term, efforts such as increasing genetic diversity, controlling invasive domestic mink, improving trapping regulations, restoring habitat, and studying the impacts of introgression could help the species reach a Functional status in nearly all spatial units. However, given the uncertainty surrounding both its current status and its potential response to conservation, the Recovery Potential remains Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Snyderman, L.S., Mychajliw, A. & Hofman, C.A.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Small Carnivore Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Daniel Wilcox (email: willcox.daniel@gmail.com) and José F. González-Maya (email: jfgonzalezmaya@gmail.com)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Will Duckworth (email: willduckworthdprk@yahoo.com)

assessments.justification:
The Annamite Striped Rabbit has a Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) as it is still Present, but threatened, in all of its spatial units. The species has a Medium Conservation Legacy; whilst it is expected that without past conservation, the larger populations in the northern and central forest blocks would have persisted, albeit in a poorer condition than is seen today, the smaller population found in the southern forest block would most likely have been lost if it were not for the protected area, due to high hunting pressures and demand for land for agriculture. Population improvements sufficient to change the state in any of the spatial units from Present to Viable are not expected in the short term, resulting in a Conservation Gain of Zero. However, in the absence of continued conservation, the smaller southern population would be expected to be extirpated within 10 years due to hunting and land clearance, resulting in a Medium Conservation Dependence. There is a reasonable area of suitable habitat remaining in two spatial units. Hunting is a key threat to this species, and anti-snare work has already been observed to have a positive impact in some national parks. With increased anti-hunting conservation interventions, as well as the establishment of a captive breeding and release programme, it is expected that the northern and central forest blocks could reach a Functional level, resulting in a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Tilker, A., Quy, L.T., Nguyen The Truong, A. & McCarthy, J.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Lagomorph Specialist Group (rabbits, pikas and hares)
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chaisr: Andrew T. Smith (email: a.smith@asu.edu) and Hayley Lanier (email: hclanier@ou.edu)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Charlotte Johnston (email: Charlotte.Johnston@asu.edu)

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Himalayan Quail being Critically Endangered, or possibly even extinct, in the single spatial unit in which it is known to have occurred. Without Schedule I protection under the Wildlife Protection Act of India (1972), which confers the highest level of legal protection, the species would most likely be extinct by now (High Conservation Legacy). If this protection was removed, the species would likely go extinct within 10 years (High Conservation Dependence). The species' Conservation Gain is Zero, as there are no additional measures planned that are expected to improve its status. However, its Recovery Potential is Medium; if the species is not extinct it would be possible to raise its Recovery Score to 35% through research, monitoring, ex situ breeding, and measures to make tourism more sustainable.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 20% (Critically Depleted) is due to the Thick-billed Parrot being Absent in 2/5 spatial units and Present in the remaining ones. The Thick-billed Parrot has a High Conservation Legacy, since without habitat and predator protection, regular health checks, and provisioning of nest boxes, the species would have likely disappeared from Mexico; it also has a High Conservation Dependence, since it is expected that if these actions do not continue, the species will be lost within 10 years. On the other hand, The Thick-billed Parrot has Zero Conservation Gain because there are not enough captive-bred birds to be released and there are no plans to reintroduce the species in the lost part of the range in the 10-year time frame. Finally, the species has a Medium Recovery Potential. Nest box provision, anti-predation measures, and health checks can contribute to Viable populations in Mexico which could potentially expand. Although Mexican breeding areas are vulnerable to illegal habitat destruction, they benefit from being difficult to access, which offers some protection. Additionally, captive breeding populations in Europe and North America could serve as assurance populations.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Enkerlin-Hoeflich, E.C., Sheppard, J., Cruz Nieto, J. & Lamberski, N.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
Tarphius floresensis has a Species Recovery Score of 33% (Largely Depleted) because it is only Functional in one of the seven spatial units in which it occurs. Of the other six, it is Absent in two, and Present but not Viable in four. Without area protection and invasive plant control to date, the sole Functional spatial unit would probably not be Functional, representing a Low (but significant) Conservation Legacy. If conservation measures were to stop now, the species would almost certainly be lost from two of the spatial units in which it is currently Present, as its forest habitat would be converted to pasture. Thus, its Conservation Dependence is Medium. As long as interventions continue, T. floresensis will retain its current state in each of the spatial units for the next 10 years. However, major improvements are unlikely in this timeframe, so the Conservation Gain is Zero. The Recovery Potential is Medium, because it would be feasible to reintroduce the species to one of the spatial units from which it has been extirpated, and restore viability to two of the spatial units that are currently assessed as Present. This will require continued removal of invasive plants, as well as the restoration or maintenance of forests to mitigate climate change induced drying.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Ferreira, M.T., Oyarzabal, G. & Cygan, M.G.W.

assessments.justification:
The Sehuencas Water Frog has a Species Recovery Score of 11% (Critically Depleted) as it is Absent in most of its indigenous range and threatened (Present) where it remains. The species has a Conservation Legacy of Zero; it has remained extant despite difficulties in effectively managing the protected area in which it is found. Given this difficulty in managing the protected area, the Conservation Dependence is also Zero; if the species has persisted despite continued disturbance to date, it will likely do so over the next 10 years. The status of the species is not expected to improve unless management improves, which is unlikely to happen over the next 10 years (Zero Conservation Gain), but if it does, over the next 100 years, at least one Viable population is possible, bringing the Recovery Score to 22% (Medium Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Camacho Badani, T. & Barrón Lavayen, S.M.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Amphibian Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Chair: Ariadne Angulo (email: aangulo@amphibians.org)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Jennifer Luedtke (email: jluedtke@amphibians.org)
Newsletter: http://www.amphibians.org/froglog/

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 25% (Largely Depleted) is due to the Mountain Nyala being threatened in the only spatial unit in which it is is known to have occurred. The species has a Low Conservation Legacy (10%) because few conservation measures were established in the past, and these had low efficacy. Given the limited size of protected areas and the general absence of law enforcement, it is believed that the species' state would only be slightly worse without these measures. With few conservation actions planned and in place for the species, there is no improvement expected in the short-term future; thus, the Conservation Gain is Zero. However, if the few actions were stopped, the species would likely decrease to even lower numbers in a 10-year time frame (persisting only in remote areas), so the species has a Low Conservation Dependence. Finally, the Mountain Nyala has a Medium Recovery Potential because its status could be substantially improved in a 100-year time frame. The government and local people have a positive attitude towards improving the species' status, so it is likely that further conservation actions will be implemented. Sustainable trophy hunting has the potential to fund effective conservation in some areas, and the Ethiopian government is actively initiating conservation plans that will hopefully reverse declines.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Satyr Tragopan has a Species Recovery Score of 56% (Moderately Depleted) as it still occurs in all its indigenous range states but is only considered Viable and Functional in Bhutan. In Bhutan, the species benefits from a national mandate to maintain 60% forest cover, without which it might cease to be Viable. Across its range, the species inhabits several protected areas, and in Nepal, it has benefitted from conservation efforts targeted towards pheasants, including monitoring, education initiatives, and alternative livelihood projects. While the impact of such actions remains unevaluated, it is possible that national populations would be smaller if they had not taken place. The Conservation Legacy is therefore assessed as Medium. Cessation of current conservation efforts would have similarly negative impacts in the short-term future, indicating a Medium Conservation Dependence. Continuing these actions is expected to maintain the species' current status in Bhutan and Nepal, and a promising community project in India has the potential to stabilise the Indian population, representing a Medium Conservation Gain. Long-term, the implementation of Other Effective Area-Based Conservation Measures (OECMs), improvements in protected area management, expansion of community-based programs, and mitigation of developmental impacts could significantly enhance the Species Recovery Score. However, uncertainty remains as to how much of the species' original habitat is intact or could be restored, leaving the Recovery Potential as Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Baral, H.S., Poudyal, L.P. & Kaul, R.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Common Birdwing's Species Recovery Score of 50% (Largely Depleted) is because, of the species' 14 spatial units, it is only Viable in five of them, and Functional in only one. The Common Birdwing's Conservation Legacy and Conservation Dependence are both Low, bordering on Indeterminate: the species was historically popular with collectors and has experienced declines in its forest habitat throughout its range; while the species is legally protected in many countries, and occurs within a number of protected areas, estimating the impacts of these actions requires more monitoring data. This is reflected in the species' Indeterminate Conservation Gain. Nonetheless, the species has a Medium Recovery Potential as much suitable habitat remains throughout the indigenous range.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Butterfly Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description: Chair and Red List Authority Coordinator: Monika Böhm (email: mbohm@indyzoo.com)

assessments.justification:
The Greater Prairie-chicken's Species Recovery Score of 50% (Largely Depleted) is due to the species only being ecologically Functional in two of its six spatial units, and one subspecies, the Heath Hen, is extinct. The Greater Prairie-chicken has a Medium Conservation Legacy; without past actions of captive breeding programmes and translocations, the Greater Prairie-chicken would have a score of 39% today. There is a Low Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species would lose functionality in one spatial unit, bringing the score to 44%. The Greater Prairie-chicken has a Conservation Gain of Zero; even with planned conservation, it is unlikely that spatial units which are not already Functional would achieve viability or functionality in 10 years' time. Even within 100 years, it is expected that the Greater Prairie-chicken could achieve viability in just one additional spatial unit; a substantial part of the range is too degraded to restore. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for the Greater Prairie-chicken is Low.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Vicuña's Species Recovery Score of 67% (Moderately Depleted) reflects widespread past decimation of the species for its valuable wool; only in the last decades has the species been restored to Viable populations across its range thanks to legal protection from hunting, an international trade ban, and the introduction of sustainable livelihood schemes. The Vicuña has a High Conservation Legacy; without this past conservation action, the Vicuña would almost certainly be close to extinction today, with a score of only 9%. There is a Medium Conservation Dependence; poaching remains a threat, and if conservation actions were to stop, it is expected that the species could become threatened across its range once more within a 10-year period, bringing the score to 34%. The Vicuña has a Medium Conservation Gain; within a 10-year period, if conservation continues, it is expected that the species could become Functional in three of four spatial units, leading to a score of 92%. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Vicuña to become Fully Recovered; relative to the current score, this represents a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The Calabrian Black Squirrel has a Species Recovery Score of 52% (Moderately Depleted) as it is Near Threatened and non-Functional in all the spatial units comprising its indigenous range, with declines in some areas. Conservation Legacy is Zero for this species: while it occurs in protected areas, the efficacy of these is variable, and the species also thrives in commercial pine plantations. For the same reasons, the species has Zero Conservation Dependence. Reforestation efforts are planned in the species' range, and this will be beneficial to the species, but not within the ten-year timeframe considered in this assessment. Therefore, Conservation Gain is assessed as Zero. However, long-term, the species could benefit significantly from reforestation efforts combined with enhanced habitat management, restoration of habitat connectivity, and captive breeding to improve genetic variation. Such efforts have the potential to lift the species into the Slightly Depleted category, reflecting a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Small Mammal Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Thomas Lacher (email: tlacher@tamu.edu) and Rosalind Kennerley (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Roslaind Kennedy (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)

assessments.justification:
The Socotra Karst Crab has a Species Recovery Score of 25% (Largely Depleted), as it is not ecologically Functional and faces a high risk of extinction within the sole spatial unit encompassing its indigenous range. Conservation efforts have only recently begun and are unlikely to have influenced the existing population, leading to a Conservation Legacy score of Zero. While newly initiated actions, such as awareness-raising and terrestrial vegetation restoration, could help prevent further declines, they are insufficient to restore the population within the next decade. Consequently, Conservation Gain is assessed as Zero, with the species expected to maintain its Current State over this period. Without conservation intervention, the population is likely to decline further, potentially reaching Critically Endangered status or, in the worst-case scenario, becoming extirpated. Ongoing threats, including habitat degradation from overgrazing and human population growth, could further reduce suitable habitat if no remedial measures are taken. Additionally, increasing poverty and lack of awareness could lead to renewed harvesting of crabs for food. Given these factors, Conservation Dependence is considered Low but significant. With targeted conservation efforts – such as restoring terrestrial habitats to maintain biodiversity, reducing localised grazing pressure, and protecting key sites (e.g. rocky surfaces, caves) from development – some subpopulations could achieve Functional status in localised areas. However, full recovery across the species' entire range may not be feasible. A realistic long-term goal would be achieving Least Concern status, reflecting a Medium Recovery Potential. However, climate change and predation by invasive species (e.g., rats, civet cats, and feral cats) introduce uncertainties.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Freshwater Crustacean Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Neil Cumberlidge (email: ncumberl@nmu.edu) and Keith Crandall (email: kcrandall@gwu.edu)
Red List Authority Coordinators:
Freshwater Crabs: Darren C.J. Yeo (email: darrenyeo@nus.edu.sg)
Crayfish: Keith Crandall (email: kcrandall@gwu.edu)
Freshwater Shrimps: Sammy DeGrave (email: sammy.degrave@oum.ox.ac.uk)

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 50% (Largely Depleted) is due to the Hispaniola Solenodon being Functional in only one spatial unit, and Present but threatened in the other two spatial units. This spatial variation in state is the result of populations being under much more human pressure in the Haiti portion of its range than the Dominican Republic portion. The species has a Medium Conservation Legacy and Dependence; this is because conservation actions are limited to habitat protection in the Dominican Republic, with no measures underway or planned in Haiti. Even so, the species is expected to persist (albeit with declines) in transformed and degraded habitats because of its resilience and generalist habits. The species has a Zero Conservation Gain and Recovery Potential because maintaining protected areas is expected to only sustain the species' status, and the situation in Haiti is unlikely to improve due to economic, social, and political factors.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Small Mammal Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Thomas Lacher (email: tlacher@tamu.edu) and Rosalind Kennerley (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Roslaind Kennedy (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)

assessments.justification:
Cavia intermedia evolved on, and has persisted on, a tiny island for around 8,000 years. Its Species Recovery Category is Indeterminate, which reflects the uncertainty around whether the species is declining; if not, because the species is expected to occur in similar numbers today as it has for centuries, it could be considered Functional. Research is ongoing to verify the population trend. The island is difficult to access, but some hunting may take place occasionally, so without legal protection of the island the species' would be expected to be worse off but still Present; therefore the Conservation Legacy and Conservation Dependence are both Medium. Looking to the future, there is some probability that a stochastic event (in this case, a fire) could drive the species to extinction within 20 years; therefore, all future scenarios include the possibility of extinction. In light of this, the Conservation Gain is Indeterminate. Because the population currently fluctuates around carrying capacity, it is unlikely that the species could increase to much higher levels, but in the long term, if there was evidence that the species was not declining and that all non-stochastic threats were not operating, the species may yet be considered Fully Recovered. However, the threat of stochastic extinction makes the Recovery Potential for this species Indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Small Mammal Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Thomas Lacher (email: tlacher@tamu.edu) and Rosalind Kennerley (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Roslaind Kennedy (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)

assessments.justification:
The Chagos Brain Coral has a Species Recovery Score of 15% (Critically Depleted), as it faces an extremely high risk of extinction in both spatial units within its indigenous range. Its Conservation Legacy is assessed as Zero due to the limited direct conservation interventions and the fact that conservation efforts are largely unable to address the primary threat – climate change. That said, it is plausible that Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) have helped mitigate or prevent additional pressures. The Conservation Dependence and Gain are also assessed as Zero for similar reasons. On a more optimistic note, with sustained conservation efforts, innovative approaches, and measurable progress in addressing climate impacts, it is possible to slow the species' decline. Over the next 100 years, this could allow the Chagos Brain Coral to improve its Red List status to Vulnerable (most likely) or even Near Threatened (at best). This projection assumes advancements in technologies that enhance the species' resilience to thermal stress and alignment of global climate policies with low-emission pathways. Accordingly, the species' Recovery Potential is assessed as Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Wilson, B., Jones, R., Head, C., Obura, D.O., Pearce-Kelly, P. & Hoffmann, M.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Coral Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Chair: David Obura (email: dobura@cordioea.net)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Both Polidoro (email: beth.polidoro@asu.edu)

assessments.justification:
Dimorphandra wilsonii has a Species Recovery Score of 18% (Critically Depleted) because it has been extirpated from much of its former range, and the few remnant populations are very small, fragmented, and threatened by human activity. The PAN Faveiros project, which is dedicated to conserving this species and its threatened relatives, has led conservation interventions such as reintroductions, awareness-raising, research, and community engagement. The Recovery Score would be 3% lower today without these measures, as many of the remnant D. wilsonii populations would be smaller and at least two would be extirpated by now (a Low, but important, Conservation Legacy). If these measures were to stop, the Recovery Score would decrease by 7% over the next 10 years due to anthropogenic pressures (a Low Conservation Dependence). As this species has a long generation length, positive outcomes of conservation will take longer than 10 years to come to fruition (hence the Conservation Gain score of Zero). However, if current efforts continue, and reintroductions are extended to all suitable areas in the species' indigenous range, a Recovery Score of 31% could be attained within 100 years (a Medium Recovery Potential).

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Fernandes, F., Fernandez, E., Martinelli, G. & da Rosa, P.
assessments.reviewer_names: Verdi, M., Queiroz, M. & Cygan, M.G.W.

assessments.justification:
The Species Recovery Score of 20% (Critically Depleted) is due to the California Condor being Absent in two of its five spatial units, and Present but not Viable in the remaining three. Despite its depleted state, the species has a High Conservation Legacy; prior to reintroductions, a remnant population of only 22 individuals remained, which would likely have been lost by now in the absence of captive breeding and reintroduction. Continued reintroductions, as well as medical intervention to treat lead poisoning, will help reintroduced populations to continue growing. However, because of the species' long lifespan, population growth will not be quick enough to attain Viable populations within 10 years; thus, the predicted Conservation Gain over this timeframe is Low. This said, if conservation measures were to stop now, the species would go into steep decline. As populations would most likely remain Present for the next 10 years, the Conservation Dependence is Zero; in this case, that signifies that the currently-small populations are not expected to go completely extinct without conservation in 10 years, but the species is unquestionably dependent on conservation to survive longer-term. In the next 100 years, it would be possible for Viable populations to be restored in four of the five spatial units, representing a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Kirkland, S., Blackford, A. & Cygan, M.G.W.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Common Muskrat has a Species Recovery Score of 67% (Moderately Depleted) because it is Viable but not Functional in all spatial units covering its indigenous range. Without conservation measures – namely, muskrat trapping regulations – the recovery score would likely be 28% lower today (a Medium Conservation Legacy). Removing this measure now would be detrimental to the species, but probably not so detrimental as to worsen its state within a decade (Zero Conservation Dependence). As far as we are aware, there are no additional conservation measures aimed at improving this species' state, so it will likely retain its current recovery score for the next 10 years (Zero Conservation Gain). However, improving habitat quality and connectivity – which will in turn strengthen the species' resistance to drought in the face of anthropogenic climate change – could increase the recovery score by 17% in a 100 year timeframe (a Medium Recovery Potential). In the northwest spatial unit, long-term solutions should be led by indigenous communities who are closely interacting with and have extensive knowledge of muskrat change through time.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Snyderman, L.S., Mychajliw, A. & Hofman, C.A.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Small Mammal Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Thomas Lacher (email: tlacher@tamu.edu) and Rosalind Kennerley (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Roslaind Kennedy (email: Rosalind.Kennerley@durrell.org)

assessments.justification:
The American Horseshoe Crab has a Species Recovery Score of 69% (Moderately Depleted). While it is Viable throughout much of its range, declines due to development, harvesting, climate change and sea level rise prevent it from being Functional save for in a few spatial units. Its Conservation Legacy is Medium; with the best estimate showing that conservation actions, including harvest management, have benefitted the species. The species has a Medium Conservation Gain and Dependence; within 10 years, the best estimate is that the species' score will increase to 83% with continued conservation, or decrease to 48% if it ceased. However, given the pressures of climate change, which affects spawning cues, and sea level rise, which reduces available spawning habitat, the species is expected in 100 years to lose those short-term gains, giving it a Recovery Potential of Zero.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Smith, D.R., Brockmann, H.J., Carmichael, R., Hallerman, E., Watson, W. & Zaldívar-Rae, J.A.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Horseshoe Crab Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Co-Chairs: Mark L. Botton (email: botton@fordham.edu) and Paul K.S. Shin (email: paulksshin@gmail.com)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Dave Smith (email: drsmith@usgs.gov)

assessments.justification:
The Scimitar-horned Oryx has a Species Recovery Score of 4% (Critically Depleted) because it is Absent from seven of the eight spatial units where it historically occurred. It is Present in only one spatial unit, Chad, thanks to a reintroduction project. Without this intervention, the species would be Extinct in the Wild (a High Conservation Legacy). Plans are underway to reintroduce the species to the Niger–Nigeria and Morocco–Western Sahara spatial units, which could increase the Recovery Score to 12% within 10 years (a High Conservation Gain). However, this prediction should be treated with caution, as it remains uncertain whether these reintroductions will occur soon enough for the reintroduced individuals to qualify as 'wild' within the assessment timeframe.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Mallon, D.P., Hoffmann, M., Wacher, T. & Whitemore, S.

assessments.justification:
The Dalmatian Pelican has a Species Recovery Score of 56% (Moderately Depleted) because it is only Functional in two of the six spatial units in which it has been known to occur (Western subpopulation of the Baltic Sea-Mediterranean (BS-Med) flyway, Eastern subpopulation of the BS-Med flyway). Of the remaining four spatial units, it is Viable but non-Functional in one (Fore-Caucasus and West Caspian populations), Present but non-Viable in two (Mongolia and China population, Central and West Asia flyway populations), and extirpated in one (Central European population). In the BS-Med flyway spatial units, concerted conservation action has brought about major improvements in the state of the species. This is not the case in the other spatial units, were conservation action has been limited. Because of the spatial heterogeneity in conservation impact, the overall Conservation Legacy is Medium. The predicted Conservation Gain is Zero, because populations will most likely retain their current state for the next 10 years if ongoing measures continue. However, if all measures were to stop, the progress made in recent decades in the BS-Med flyway spatial units would be lost: the Conservation Dependence is Medium. If conservation actions implemented in the BS-Med flyway units were expanded to other areas, and reintroductions were performed in the extirpated Central European spatial unit, the Recovery Score could increase to 84%, representing a Medium Recovery Potential.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.reviewer_names: Tarasov, V., Bugariu, S., Alexandrou, O. & Cygan, M.G.W.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)

assessments.justification:
The Blue Shark has a Species Recovery Score of 43% (Largely Depleted) due to its threatened or Near Threatened status in four of the six spatial units within its indigenous range. In the remaining two units, the species is Viable but not fulfilling its ecological functions at baseline levels. In some spatial units, specific conservation measures for Blue Sharks—such as catch limits and mandatory data reporting—are in place. In other units, while there are no targeted conservation measures for the species, broader shark protections exist, including reporting requirements, bans on shark lines and finning, and bycatch reduction measures. While these regulations have likely had a positive impact, Blue Shark bycatch remains high and continues to increase, leading to a Low Conservation Legacy assessment. If all current restrictions and regulations were removed, shark exploitation would likely rise across the species' range, further deteriorating its status. In the Mediterranean spatial unit, where overfishing is severe and the species is already in a critical state, the removal of protections could lead to local extirpation within a decade. As a result, the species is assessed as having Medium Conservation Dependence. If existing measures remain in place, the species is expected to maintain its overall status over the next decade, with some regions improving while others decline—resulting in a net Zero Conservation Gain. In the long term, with maximum conservation effort, the species' condition could improve significantly, reflecting a Medium Recovery Potential. Achieving this would require strict enforcement of catch limits and a temporary suspension of large-scale commercial fishing in the Mediterranean spatial unit.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Polo-Silva, C.J., Blanco-Parra, M.P., Barrera-Garcia, A., Araujo, G. & Scotts, G.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Shark Specialist Group (sharks and rays)
ssc_groups.description:
Chair: Rima Jabado (email: rimajabado@hotmail.com)
Red List Authority Coordinator: Cassie Rigby (email: crigby@westnet.com.au)

assessments.justification:
Since the previous Green Status of Species assessment for the Saiga (Milner-Gulland 2021), the Saiga's Species Recovery Score has increased from 38% to 48%. Whilst it is still classified as Largely Depleted, it is now close to the threshold for Moderately Depleted due to conservation efforts improving the status of the species in two spatial units. However, it is still extirpated in some parts of its indigenous range, and threatened in parts of the remaining extant range. The Saiga has a High Conservation Legacy; without past conservation action, the Saiga would likely have gone extinct in one spatial unit, and would have lost viability and functionality in others, resulting in a score of 29%. Some of the positive effects of conservation have been masked somewhat by disease outbreaks, which have knocked the species back to levels lower than what had been achieved through concerted conservation, but population recovery has been observed since disease outbreaks, with one population recovering to a Functional state since the last Green Status of Species assessment. There is a High Conservation Dependence; if conservation actions like habitat protections and veterinary care were to stop, it is expected that the species' status would deteriorate in most spatial units over a 10-year period, and functionality is expected to be lost from all spatial units. The Saiga has a Medium Conservation Gain: within a 10-year period, if conservation continues, it is expected that two more spatial units will become Viable; combined with the planned reintroduction to a spatial unit where the species is currently Absent, a Green Score of 62% is expected to be achieved. Finally, within 100 years it would be possible for the Saiga to achieve a Green Score of 62%, the same as is anticipated for 10 years as some areas of the indigenous range are unlikely to provide suitable habitat even in the long term, and where there is suitable habitat it was deemed likely that the species could become Viable or Functional within 10 years. Due to there being uncertainty around whether some spatial units could support Viable or Functional populations in the long-term, largely due to human infrastructure, the Recovery Potential for the Saiga is indeterminate.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.

The African Penguin's Species Recovery Score of 33% represents the species' threatened status in all of its spatial units; the species has greatly declined since the late 1800s, first from egg collecting and guano scraping and later, in the mid-1900s, due to industrial fishing. The African Penguin has a High Conservation Legacy; without protected areas, the African Penguin would possibly be extinct today. Conservation Dependence and Conservation Gain are both Zero: the species would likely not disappear from any spatial units within 10 years without conservation; with conservation, the species is not expected to become Viable in any spatial units within 10 years, given the species' slow reproduction. However, within 100 years it would be possible for the African Penguin to become Viable in three out of four spatial units, leading to a score of 58%. Therefore, the Recovery Potential for the African Penguin is Medium.

For additional data, see the Supplementary Information document.
assessments.assessor_names: Hagen , C., McInnes, A., Waller, L.J. & Stephenson, P.J.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Bird Red List Authority (BirdLife International)
ssc_groups.description: Red List Authority Coordinator: Ian Burfield (ian.burfield@birdlife.org)
